🚨‼️BREAKING: Zelenskyy Urges U.S. to Boost Gas Supplies to Europe as Ukraine Halts Russian Gas Flow

After decades of dependency, Russian gas exports through Ukraine have been halted, marking a significant shift in European energy dynamics. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has called on the United States to step up and supply more gas to Europe, filling the void left by Russia.

This decision comes amid escalating tensions, further severing Europe’s reliance on Russian energy. The U.S. now faces pressure to support its allies with increased gas exports as Europe scrambles to secure alternative sources.

Stay tuned for updates as this energy crisis unfolds.

Tesla missed its delivery numbers. How important is this?

For the first time since its inception, Tesla delivered less vehicles than the year before. And while it is certainly notable, it is also important to consider that Tesla doesn't trade like a car company and certainly isn't valued as one. 

My take: The miss by about 10k from the whisper number and 20k to achieve Y/Y growth may lead to a short downward pressure after Tesla's remarkable run in Q4, but it doesn't change the thesis of the company and what its investors are in it for. 

1. Autonomy and FSD
2. AI, Robotics and Humanoid Robotics 
3. Energy Capture and innovation 

Trading at around 5x higher (forward PE) than its Mag 7 cohort and 8-12x higher than its automotive peers. Tesla is a car company that isn't a car company. And this will likely lead to bigger swings with exponentially more upside. 

If you want safer exposure to AI or Tech then I see the likes of Google, NVIDIA, Microsoft, Meta, Amazon, and Apple as a safer play. But I don't think Tesla investors are in it for safe. They are in it for the big wins. Always have been. So, today's number means a little, but not much. 

The real question is whether Elon can achieve the vision of autonomy, and humanoid robots? Its investors clearly believe it can. And I tend to not bet against Musk. Maybe his timelines, but not the ultimate outcome.

Trade Recap Of The Day: $QQQ 517c 01/03 @.64 for a gain of 143% 

Why did I take this trade?

- First of all, my bias from the open was bullish as $NVDA was absolutely rocketing right at open. $TSLA also saw some nice strength, as some other large caps did too. 

- My second, and main reasoning for entering the trade was the beautiful bounce from the premarket low ($513.54). As you can see on the chart below, right before my entry, there was a huge red candle which test below this level and bounced right back up. 

- After that red candle formed, I waited for the retest and bounce to confirm my upside bias, and when we retested (see the candle on my entry in the chart below), I entered the play.

- My main target was the $516.60 level, as this was a major level we kept rejecting since yesterday (also see the circles on my chart below).

This was a brief explanation of why I entered this trade!

U.S. Chamber, oil industry sue Vermont over law requiring companies to pay for climate change damage | Lisa Rathke & Michael Casey, CTV News

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and a top oil and gas industry trade group are suing Vermont over its new law requiring that fossil fuel companies pay a share of the damage caused over several decades by climate change.

The federal lawsuit filed Monday asks a state court to prevent Vermont from enforcing the law, which was passed last year. Vermont became the first state in the country to enact the law after it suffered catastrophic summer flooding and damage from other extreme weather. The state is working to estimate the cost of climate change dating back to Jan. 1, 1995.

The lawsuit argues the U.S. Constitution precludes the act and that the state law is preempted by the federal Clean Air Act. It also argues that the law violates domestic and foreign commerce clauses by discriminating “against the important interest of other states by targeting large energy companies located outside of Vermont.”

The Chamber and the other plaintiff in the lawsuit, the American Petroleum Institute, argue that the federal government is already addressing climate change. And because greenhouse gases come from billions of individual sources, they argue it is impossible to measure “accurately and fairly” the impact of emissions from a particular entity in a particular location over decades.

“Vermont wants to impose massive retroactive penalties going back 30 years for lawful, out-of-state conduct that was regulated by Congress under the Clean Air Act," said Tara Morrissey, senior vice president and deputy chief counsel of the Chamber’s litigation center. “That is unlawful and violates the structure of the U.S. Constitution — one state can’t try to regulate a global issue best left to the federal government. Vermont’s penalties will ultimately raise costs for consumers in Vermont and across the country.”

A spokesman for the state's Agency of Natural Resources said it had not been formally served with this lawsuit.

Anthony Iarrapino, a Vermont-based lobbyist with the Conservation Law Foundation, said the lawsuit was the fossil fuel industry's way of “trying to avoid accountability for the damage their products have caused in Vermont and beyond.”

“More states are following Vermont’s lead holding Big Oil accountable for the disaster recovery and cleanup costs from severe storms fueled by climate change, ensuring that families and businesses no longer have to foot the entire bill time and time again," Iarrapino added.

The following graphic from the Frauenhofer Institute illustrates that Germany has achieved an enormous success story in the field of renewable energy transformation by 2024.

In a groundbreaking partnership, @KinetixFi and @PythNetwork are bridging the $10 trillion global energy market with decentralized finance (DeFi). For the first time, DeFi users can trade West Texas Intermediate (WTI) and Brent crude oil indexes directly on-chain, leveraging real-world assets for better portfolio diversification.

Unlocking Energy Trading in DeFi

This integration marks a significant milestone in the evolution of DeFi. By bringing WTI and Brent crude oil benchmarks on-chain, Kinetix and Pyth Network are providing:

- Real-world assets(#RWA) for improved portfolio diversification
- Access to two of the most critical crude oil benchmarks globally
- A seamless and decentralized trading experience

Pyth Network: The Power Behind Accurate Pricing

Pyth Network, a leading provider of real-time market data, plays a crucial role in this partnership. By delivering accurate and reliable pricing for WTI and Brent crude oil directly on-chain, Pyth Network ensures that DeFi traders have access to the same high-quality data as traditional market participants.

Why This Matters

This collaboration has far-reaching implications for DeFi:

- Ensures real-world accuracy for commodity trading in DeFi
- Leverages decentralized oracles for transparent and secure data

⭕How much is the battle against Russian natural gas costing Europe?

Even though the European allies have been loudly declaring for a while now how they have to steer clear of Russian energy imports, it turns out that walking the walk is not the same as talking the talk.
 
European states today purchase a “record amount” of Russian liquefied natural gas, Bloomberg notes, adding that these exports have surpassed those of the gas Russia used to ship to Europe via the pipeline that runs through Ukraine. 
 
News of this development comes as the European Commission acknowledged this week that gas storage facilities in the EU are depleting at a faster rate than they did last year, following Ukraine's suspension of Russian natural gas transit to Europe. 
 
Meanwhile, Hungary’s Foreign Minister, Peter Szijjarto, noted that the price of natural gas in the European market has surged by 20% since Ukraine officially announced its decision to halt Russian gas transit last month. 
 
In their determination to undermine Russia, regardless of the repercussions for their own economies, the European allies of the United States might very well be contenders for the title of the world's foremost champions of self-sabotage.
|@geopolitics_live

How much is the battle against Russian natural gas costing Europe?

Even though the European allies have been loudly declaring for a while now how they have to steer clear of Russian energy imports, it turns out that walking the walk is not the same as talking the talk.
 
European states today purchase a “record amount” of Russian liquefied natural gas, Bloomberg notes, adding that these exports have surpassed those of the gas Russia used to ship to Europe via the pipeline that runs through Ukraine. 
 
News of this development comes as the European Commission acknowledged this week that gas storage facilities in the EU are depleting at a faster rate than they did last year, following Ukraine's suspension of Russian natural gas transit to Europe. 
 
Meanwhile, Hungary’s Foreign Minister, Peter Szijjarto, noted that the price of natural gas in the European market has surged by 20% since Ukraine officially announced its decision to halt Russian gas transit last month. 
 
In their determination to undermine Russia, regardless of the repercussions for their own economies, the European allies of the United States might very well be contenders for the title of the world's foremost champions of self-sabotage.

After termination of transit of Russian gas through Ukraine, gas price in Europe increased by 20% — Hungarian FM

"Since the termination of the gas transit route through Ukraine became final in mid-December, the price of natural gas on the European market has increased by 20%," Peter Szijjarto wrote on his Facebook page.

Hungary was not affected by Ukraine's decision to stop gas transit from Russia, but this means new challenges for the entire EU, the Hungarian foreign minister added.

Iraq Surpasses Saudi Arabia in Weekly Oil Exports to US

The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) announced on Saturday that Iraq was the second-largest oil exporter to the United States during the past week, surpassing Saudi Arabia.
The EIA mentioned that the average US imports of crude oil during the past week from nine major countries reached approximately 5.76 million barrels per day, representing a decline of 79,000 barrels per day compared to the previous week, when US oil imports reached 5.84 million barrels per day, Shafaq News reported.

Iraq’s oil exports to the United States reached 212,000 barrels per day last week, representing a decline of 17,000 barrels per day compared to the previous week, when Iraq exported 229,000 barrels per day to the US.

The EIA indicated that most of the United States imports of crude oil during the past week came from Canada at an average of 3.73 million barrels per day, followed by Mexico with an average of 551,000 barrels per day and Venezuela with an average of 353,000 barrels per day.

The United States imported an average of 289,000 barrels per day from Colombia, 280,000 barrels per day from Brazil, 189,000 barrels per day from Libya, 87,000 barrels per day from Saudi Arabia, and 71,000 barrels per day from Nigeria.

This action, coordinated with the UK, marks an effort to restrict Russia's primary revenue source for funding its war in Ukraine.

The truth about used cooking oil (UCO) imports: Are fake foreign blends undermining American farmers and biofuels? Learn how U.S. lawmakers are stepping up to protect domestic agriculture and renewable fuel standards. 🌽🇺🇸 Don’t miss this quick breakdown of a critical issue impacting our economy and environment! #UCO #Biofuels #AgriculturePolicy

In 2024, China made a dramatic shift in its energy strategy by significantly reducing its imports of U.S. crude oil, dropping by nearly 46% compared to the previous year. This change reshapes global energy dynamics, as China, which had been the second-largest importer of U.S. crude, now falls to the sixth position in the global rankings. 

With imports down to 81.9 million barrels in 2024 from 115.6 million barrels in 2023, this move signals a broader transformation in China’s approach to energy procurement. This reduction in U.S. crude imports is part of a larger trend in China’s energy landscape, where the country’s overall crude imports have also decreased by 7.2%. Factors like intermittent COVID-19 lockdowns, high domestic inventories, and refinery maintenance have contributed to this downturn. 

However, China’s energy strategy is evolving, with the country increasingly turning to alternative suppliers, particularly from politically isolated nations like Russia, Iran, and Venezuela. These countries offer China discounted crude, allowing refiners to secure lower-cost energy while diversifying supply sources and strengthening energy security. 

China’s imports from Russia, Iran, and Venezuela have increased significantly, making up a larger portion of China’s crude oil supply. This shift is driven by economic benefits, as these nations offer cheaper oil due to Western sanctions. In turn, China’s engagement with these countries enhances its geopolitical leverage and reduces its dependence on U.S. energy exports, providing a strategic advantage in the ongoing trade tensions between the U.S. and China. 

This pivot in China’s oil import strategy not only reshapes its energy security but also has far-reaching consequences for the global oil market. It challenges the effectiveness of Western sanctions and exposes vulnerabilities in global energy supply chains, potentially influencing global oil pricing and production strategies. As China strengthens ties with non-Western suppliers, such as Russia and Iran, it positions itself as a central player in the future of global energy markets, with far-reaching implications for U.S.-led frameworks

INDUSTRIAL POLICY LESSONS FROM INDONESIA ON NICKEL

1. Indonesia has the world’s largest reserves of nickel, which is important for making electric-vehicle (EV) batteries.

2. In 2014, the country moved to ban exports of unprocessed ores, and since 2020, when the export ban came into full force, it has come to dominate the nickel market.

3. Dozens of nickel smelters have opened since 2020, led by Chinese smelters. These smelters have proven very innovative in refining once-thought non-commercial Indonesian nickel-ore deposits at scale.

4. Indonesia’s share of the world’s refined nickel production has doubled since 2020 (about 50% of the total).

5. In 2023, Indonesia exported $22bn of processed nickel (9% of the country’s total exports) compared with 2% in 2019.

6. The nickel bonanza lifted Indonesia’s trade surplus to a record high in 2022.

7. The next step is for Indonesia to specialise in parts of the EV supply chain, such as nickel-battery 
precursors.

We believe that it is unlikely (<25% chance) that President Trump will place tariffs on Canadian oil. How can he do so (60% of US imports) while also committing to "maximum pressure" on Iran (1.7MM Bbl/d) and enforcing new sanctions on Russia (0.75-1.5MM Bbl/d) and Venezuela (~0.1MM Bbl/d and an alternative to CDN heavy oil). Further, PADD 2 imports ~3MM Bbl/d from Canada via pipeline with limited/no alternatives. Tariffs also assumed direct pass through to US consumer = inflationary when US 10 year treasuries at 4.6%. 

I met with the CEOs of most CDN oil companies earlier this week and no strong views other than would be temporary and "this too shall pass." 

Canadian energy names have lagged their US peers by ~8% since Premier Smith's comments spooked the market. With WTI spot at $78 and 2025 strip at $73 some names are trading at 17%-19% free cashflow yields at $75. A full tariff (and likely VERY temporary) would lower this to still over 10%. While knee jerk reactions are always possible/likely, given the lag in CDN names to the recent rise in WTI fundamentally valuations in several names are already discounting a full tariff. 

We are seeing tariff angst amongst clients and trading desks report heavy US HF selling/shorting. Uncertainty creates opportunity and while no one can be truly certain on the outcome, to us this has become an alpha generating opportunity, with clarity in the coming weeks.

Eric Nuttall - January 16, 2025: In this week's update, @ericnuttall , Senior Portfolio Manager of Ninepoint Energy Strategies shares key insights from the Peters & Co. Oil Conference in Calgary, including meetings with CEOs of major oil and gas companies. He discusses the outlook for Canadian and U.S. energy stocks, the impact of potential tariffs on Canadian oil, and the discipline (or lack thereof) in natural gas production.

Eric also explores the market dynamics of $80 oil, OPEC+ strategies, and how geopolitical pressures—like sanctions on Russia and Iran—are shaping global supply and demand. If you’re navigating the energy markets in 2025, this is a must-watch!

Key Topics Covered:

• Tariff Concerns: The potential impact of U.S. tariffs on Canadian oil and why they may be short-lived.
• $80 Oil Price Outlook: Why every day above $80 is a gift and what it means for energy investors.
• OPEC+ Strategy: Insights on Saudi Arabia and OPEC’s approach to production cuts and oil price stabilization.
• Natural Gas Market: Why U.S. gas producers are showing more discipline compared to their Canadian counterparts.
• Pipeline Challenges: The ongoing struggles of Canadian pipeline projects and the urgent need for capacity expansion.
• Share Buybacks: Companies capitalizing on high oil prices to repurchase shares and return value to investors.
• Sanctions and Geopolitics: The effects of U.S. sanctions on Russia and Iran and their implications for oil prices.

Should Alberta halt oil exports to the United States? Albertans weigh in

The oil and gas industry is back in the political spotlight, with Alberta Premier Danielle Smith clashing with Trudeau and her fellow premiers over energy policies and economic priorities.

The height of the controversy began earlier this week when the federal government brought the idea of cutting off energy supply to the U.S. and imposing export tariffs on Alberta energy and other products to the United States. Alberta Premier Danielle Smith responded to these threats by saying it would spark a “national unity crisis”. She then flipped off the Trudeau Liberals’ stance, declaring that Alberta would not comply with export tariffs on its oil, gas, and other resources, nor support an outright export ban.

This stems from the statements made by the incoming President of the United States, Donald Trump, who has threatened to impose a 25% export tariff on Canadian goods, citing concerns over border security. He argued that failure to enforce stricter border policies warrants consequences for Canada.

Canada’s premiers and outgoing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met to discuss the challenges and explore possible solutions. However, the Alberta premier strongly opposed the proposals put forward. Smith claimed the policies would strangle Alberta’s economy and accused Ottawa of ignoring provincial rights to control their natural resources.

Instead, she urged Canadians to use this tariff threat as an “opportunity to correct” the misguided direction of this country.” She plans to meet with U.S. lawmakers and officials to make a case against the imposition of tariffs on Canada.

Rebel News took to the streets of downtown Calgary to speak to Albertans about their thoughts on the tariff war between the United States and Canada.

WHAT NIGERIA STANDS TO GAIN FROM BRICS

Nigeria was recently admitted as a “partner country” of the BRICS bloc of developing economies, according to Brazil, the group’s chair.

Economically, Nigeria can benefit from increased trade with BRICS nations, especially in oil, gas, agriculture, and manufacturing, which may reduce its dependence on Western economies. Investment from BRICS countries could lead to infrastructure growth and job creation. Being part of BRICS may also help Nigeria reduce reliance on the US dollar for trade, potentially using local currencies or a new BRICS currency.

Politically, Nigeria gains a stronger global voice, potentially influencing international policies and representing African interests. The partnership opens doors to strategic alliances with influential emerging economies. Developmentally, Nigeria could benefit from technological transfers in fields like renewable energy, digital infrastructure, and space technology.

Although Nigeria has been admitted as a partner country, its participation in decision-making will be limited, lacking full membership privileges like voting rights. Nonetheless, Nigeria's inclusion in BRICS signals its rising status in global politics and economics.

The end of an era: How Europe is adapting to the halt of Russian gas via Ukraine

As predicted by Kpler Insight, #gas flows from Slovakia to Austria and Czechia ceased on January 1st. Both countries have increased imports from Germany, primarily benefiting from the lifting of the cross-border gas storage levy, with flows routed through the Brandov and Oberkappel VIPs.

Poland has also halted gas imports via interconnections with Ukraine and Czechia, confirming it had been indirectly sourcing Russian gas through Ukraine until the stoppage. Underground gas storage withdrawals in Slovakia, Austria, and Poland have risen as market players adapt to the evolving supply dynamics.

#LNG will remain central to replacing Russian volumes by 2025, with import capacity in Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Croatia, Greece, and Italy serving as a critical backbone. However, infrastructure bottlenecks along key gas corridors will likely constrain short-term diversification strategies in the CEE region.

Key factors to watch include negotiations to end the Russia-Ukraine war, delays in LNG projects, sanctions on Russian LNG, higher cross-border tariffs, and flow congestion—each shaping Europe's gas supply dynamics.

Alberta Premier Danielle Smith is getting support from an unlikely ally for refusing to sign on to a communique that would have curbed US oil exports — Ontario’s manufacturing sector.

That’s because the Coalition of Concerned Manufacturers and Businesses of Canada (CCMBC) has expressed strong support for Smith in her firm stance against Ottawa’s energy policies and potential US tariffs despite pressure from Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and fellow premiers including Ontario’s Doug Ford.

CCMBC president Catherine Swift praised Smith’s strong stance and leadership, stating, “Despite pressure from federal Liberals… and other provincial premiers, Premier Smith is the one truly standing up for Canada’s interests.”

The controversy stems from a communiqué signed by all premiers except Smith, addressing possible retaliatory measures against US tariffs.

Both Smith and Saskatchewan’s Scott Moe argued that the document could have been revised to allow Alberta’s participation without compromising its core intent. Instead, Swift suggested, “Trudeau used this as an opportunity to be divisive, scapegoating Alberta and Smith for not being part of ‘Team Canada’.”

Swift criticized the Trudeau government’s history of targeting Alberta’s energy sector, citing the 1970s National Energy Policy (NEP) and subsequent restrictions on Alberta oil and gas. In that regard, history is repeating itself, she argued.

“Given the federal government’s track record, Smith is right to approach this situation with caution. What we needed was for all premiers to unite against the weak economic policies of the federal Liberal government that have left Canada in a vulnerable position,” said Swift.

Smith’s refusal to align with the federal government has drawn backlash, but the CCMBC contends her stance protects more than just Alberta. “Many manufacturers and businesses across Canada, including those in Ontario, rely heavily on Alberta’s oil and gas sector. By defending this vital Canadian export, Premier Smith is safeguarding not only Alberta’s interests but those of the entire country,” Swift emphasized.

The CCMBC, founded in 2016, advocates for policies that support manufacturing, business retention, and job growth across Canada. Swift underscored the coalition’s shared goal with Smith: “to ensure economic resilience and competitiveness in the face of both domestic and international challenges.”

The Iraqi Parliament has once again postponed the approval of a crucial budget amendment related to the oil exports of the Kurdistan Region. The amendment, which has sparked heated debate, centers around the payment terms for oil production and transportation in the Kurdish-controlled areas.

In a move that has further intensified the ongoing dispute, Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia' Al Sudani has proposed a new clause demanding that the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) hand over its natural gas and oil components to Baghdad. This proposal was sent to the Iraqi Parliament, triggering an impasse that has delayed the budget amendment yet again.

Soran Omar, a Kurdish member of the Iraqi Parliament, confirmed. According to Omar, the introduction of this new clause regarding the handover of oil and gas resources has complicated the discussions, leading to the lack of approval for the amendment. He stated, “This new proposal by the Prime Minister has caused problems, and the amendment was not approved as a result.”

The new clause is part of the Iraqi government's efforts to secure control over the oil and gas resources in the Kurdistan Region, which has long been a source of tension between Erbil and Baghdad. While the KRG has maintained its autonomy in managing these resources, the Iraqi government insists on more centralized control as part of its national economic strategy.

The parliamentary session on January 19, 2025, also saw the rejection of a proposal concerning the Kurdistan Region’s oil exports. This proposal aimed to set a provisional payment rate of $16 per barrel for the region's oil production and transportation. The Finance Committee had reviewed the amendment, which would have provided financial relief to the Kurdistan Region, but it was met with strong opposition from Shiite lawmakers. 
➡️( This is not the HCL Law BTW It is the $16 per barrel is payment from the federal government to the KRG for oil, which would then be adjusted against what the KRG owes the Iraqi federal government )

Omar explained that the vote could not take place because the quorum requirement for legal attendance was not met. Shiite legislators argued that $16 per barrel was an excessive amount compared to the $8 per barrel allocated for oil production in southern Iraq. However, KRG leaders had previously insisted on a higher rate of $26 per barrel due to the elevated costs of oil extraction in the region, leading to the compromise figure of $16. 

Escalation of Oil Smuggling Activities

Amidst these political disagreements, there has been a significant increase in oil smuggling activities from the Kurdistan Region to neighboring countries, particularly Iran and Turkey. Following the closure of the official export pipeline in March 2023, a clandestine network has emerged, facilitating the transport of oil via tanker trucks.

Reports indicate that over 1,000 tankers are involved in transporting at least 200,000 barrels of oil daily. This illicit trade is estimated to generate approximately $200 million per month.The oil is sold at significantly reduced prices, ranging between $30 to $40 per barrel, roughly half the global market rate. Despite the substantial revenue generated, the proceeds from these operations are not accounted for in the official coffers of the KRG, raising concerns about transparency and governance. 
➡️( KRG is not sending this to the Iraqi federal government, like all the other Regional Governments in Iraq do)

The smuggling operations have also attracted international attention due to potential violations of sanctions, particularly those imposed by the United States on Iran. The unregulated nature of these transactions poses significant risks, including environmental hazards and the undermining of official economic channels.

Implications for Regional Stability

The deadlock on the budget amendment, coupled with the surge in oil smuggling, has exacerbated the financial crisis in the Kurdistan Region. With official oil revenues suspended and no legal export avenues available, the region faces mounting economic challenges.

Tensions between the Iraqi federal government and the KRG continue to escalate, with implications for both regional stability and the international oil companies operating within the Kurdistan Region.The KRG is under increasing pressure, with lawmakers warning that the unresolved budget issue could lead to further economic difficulties and deepen the rift between Erbil and Baghdad.

Soran Omer have also expressed concern that the failure to pass the budget amendment could lead to the continuation of illicit oil sales, a practice that could undermine the region's economic recovery while depriving its citizens of much-needed revenue. The ongoing standoff between the two sides shows no signs of resolution, leaving the Kurdistan Region in a vulnerable position with little prospect for a swift solution.

Türkiye is positioning itself as a key energy partner for the EU, leveraging the need for alternative gas routes after the Russia-Ukraine transit deal ended.

Ankara seeks to restart energy talks with the EU to enhance cooperation in energy, trade, and regional political issues. 

Turkish EU ambassador Faruk Kaymakcı highlighted Turkey’s role, stating, “Türkiye is one of the three or four main energy arteries—whether to use it or not is up to the EU.”

Talks were stalled in 2019 over Mediterranean gas disputes involving Turkey, Cyprus, and Greece. Kaymakcı called the situation a “lose-lose” and noted Cyprus remains the main obstacle to resuming dialogue.

With TurkStream now the sole route for Russian gas to Europe, Türkiye’s importance has grown. Energy analyst Kadri Tastan remarked, “TurkStream is becoming far more important… strengthening Turkey’s position.”

Meanwhile, Hungary and Slovakia, reliant on Russian gas, are concerned about supply disruptions. 

Hungarian PM Viktor Orbán even threatened to block EU sanctions on Russia unless Kyiv reopened transit routes.

Source: Politico

Syrian authorities have started the rehabilitation of the Baniyas refinery, Syria's largest oil refining facility, after its operations were suspended due to the disruption of crude oil supplies from Iran, which accounted for the bulk of the country's oil imports.

Ibrahim Muslim, director of the refinery, confirmed to Bloomberg Al-Sharq that repair work has been carried out at the facility with the aim of reactivating it and increasing its production capacity from the current 90,000 barrels per day to 110,000 barrels per day.

This refinery is one of the two key refineries for the Syrian authorities in supplying local demand, given that the capacity of the Homs refinery is approximately 100,000 barrels per day.

What would happen if Trump imposed tariffs on Canadian crude oil?

Tariffs would make Canadian crude oil too expensive to supply to US refiners, which would have to replace Canadian crude oil with heavy crude oil imported from Latin America or the Middle East.

~90% of Canadian crude oil exported to the US is transported via pipeline systems, and the majority is WCS grade, which is heavy sour crude oil. 

TMX accounts for only 5% of the flow. ~200 kb/d of TMX volume will be re-routed to head from Vancouver to North Asia, and this change in flow is bullish for freight rates.

Tariffs could reduce Canadian crude oil production. If demand for WCS from the PADD 2 refineries decreases, Canada will need alternative sales outlets because the Vancouver alternative route has limited capacity. Therefore, it will have to export through USGC ports.

However, it is unlikely that all of these large volumes will be accepted by USGC ports. The fact that US light oil production has reached its limit is also related to the limited export capacity, and more crude oil will be converted to exports as the LyondellBasell refinery begins to shut down.

Therefore, it is not possible to export all of the volumes over 3mb/d that are subject to tariffs through USGC ports. 

Combining the existing ~4mb/d of WTI exports and ~3.5mb/d of Canadian crude oil exports amounts to ~7.5mb/d, which is well in excess of the USGC export capacity.

In conclusion, there will be a shortage of at least 1.5mb/d of Canadian crude oil export routes. 

As a result, either Canada must reduce production or the marginal cost of importing US crude oil must rise sharply. American taxpayers will be forced to pay for the massive increase in fuel prices.

Therefore, Trump's imposition of tariffs on Canadian crude oil is not easy. If he really does it, he's crazy.

CHINA HITS BACK WITH NEW RETALIATORY TARIFFS ON U.S. GOODS - FT

Starting Monday, China will impose tariffs of up to 15% on $14B worth of U.S. goods, including LNG, coal, crude oil, farm equipment, and certain vehicles, according to the FT. The move comes in retaliation to Trump's additional 10% levy on Chinese imports.

China is also targeting critical U.S. industries by restricting exports of rare earth metals used in defense, EV batteries, and solar panels. With 60% of global rare earth production and 90% of processing, Beijing’s actions underline its dominance in the supply chain.

Trump has yet to engage in negotiations, stating he’s in “no rush” to speak with Xi Jinping. Meanwhile, analysts warn these tariffs could be a prelude to even stricter trade measures, fueling uncertainty in global markets.

$TSLA - Trade Review

This is Oversold bounce at key level

Setup - 
1. Identify Oversold - I do not use RSI, for me visual is enough, but for starters, folks can use RSI @ 15-minute granularity. Look at the historical chart to see the turning points.

2. Identify major and minor key levels - I used 350 as it is psych level and also minor higher-low
3. Do not rush into entries at open

Entries
3.  I used Bookmap to identify the liquidity zone. 350 was lining up with my level and liquidity (Refer to bookmap chart)
4. How the stock reacts near the level is essential. 
Two things that I look for
      a. Low volume into or near the level -
      b. Selling high volume and recapture
5. I tend to predict low of the day and keep my entries close to it

Stop
6. Low of the day if buying after the recapture 
or
7. Below the band if aggressive entry - I used 349

Trade Management
8. Trim > 5R (if possible), the region for trim is prior level if any for example 360 to 363 was previous zone, 
361 will trigger red to green move, so I took my profit 75 (Blue line).  This is a 5R first trim

9. Raising stop -left it as is

Breakdown of their exports in 2022:

Palm Oil ($28.7B).
Ferroalloys ($13.7B).
Petroleum Gas ($11.8B).
Coal Briquettes ($50.8B).

Their Copper Ore exported mostly to China ($67.7B), United States ($31.6B), Japan ($26.6B), India ($25.3B) & Malaysia ($15.6B).

In 2023, Indonesia produced 47 million tonnes of crude palm oil. They exported a total of $298 billion worth of goods in the same year as well.

Indonesia is the biggest exporter of palm oil in the world. They control 56% of global palm oil exports. Palm Oil sector is 4.5% of their GDP. Their Palm Oil sector provides 16.2 million Indonesians with direct & indirect jobs.

In 2023, they exported a total of $11.4 billion worth of Palm Oil to China, India & Pakistan.

Nigeria has reached new agreements with Algeria and Niger to advance the long-delayed $13 billion Trans-Saharan Gas Pipeline (TSGP), a project aimed at boosting gas exports to Europe.

Officials from the three countries formalised the agreements during a meeting in Algiers on 11 February, covering an updated feasibility study, compensation framework, and a Non-Disclosure Agreement among participating companies.

Special Assistant to President Bola Tinubu on Social Media, Dada Olusegun, confirmed that the deals involve energy firms from the three nations and mark a significant step towards actualising the project.

“The TSGP is a strategic initiative to transport natural gas from Nigeria through Niger to Algeria, where it will be exported to European and global markets,” Olusegun stated.

🎉Iraqi President ratifies Budget Law amendment on Kurdistan oil exports🎉

Iraqi President Abdul Latif Jamal Rashid ratified the first amendment to the Federal Budget Law mandating the export of oil from the Kurdistan Region through the State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO), a senior Kurdish official revealed on Sunday.
Amanj Rahim, Secretary of Kurdistan’s Council of Ministers,stated on Facebook, “The amendment to Budget Law No. 13 of 2023 stipulates that proceeds from Kurdish oil sales will be deposited into the Federal Treasury after deducting production and transportation costs.”
“The ratified amendment will come into legal force once published in the Iraqi Official Gazette,” Rahim explained, adding that this final step is pending.
Earlier this month, the Iraqi Parliament passed the first amendment to the Federal Budget Law for 2023-2025, despite a boycott by around 50 lawmakers representing central and southern provinces, and legal disputes over the session’s legitimacy.

Yes, the gas pipeline which will connect the Nigerian gas to European markets is a great playbook.  But as that happens, I want to challenge Nigerian leaders to also implement a gas pipeline that will take Nigerian gas to Nigerian markets!

Many years ago, I was a FUTO intern in NNPC: go to Owaza NNPC flow station to learn from engineers, and seasonally go to Aba to read the meters for billing. In other words, markets like Aba had gas supplies pipelined from the flow station, supporting Aba ceramics, glass and other industries. Today, most of those infrastructures have disappeared.

That brings to my request: can the federal government design and implement a gas pipeline that connects Nigerian markets instead of rushing to export gas to Europe for their companies? We have local companies in Nigeria which need gas and we are not doing much to make gas available to them. My model is a gas pipeline network that connects at least two  cities per state.

I am not saying that Nigeria should not sell to Europe, I am saying that it is unfortunate that this pipeline to Europe is passing Onitsha, and some of our core markets, with no provision for local companies to tap the gas. 🚨NEWS: Tesla braces for delay to China licence as Trump trade tensions mount

Tesla is bracing for a potential delay in obtaining Chinese approval for its autonomous driving technology, as Elon Musk’s electric-vehicle company risks getting dragged into the escalating US-China trade war. 

The company has been told there is no definitive timetable for regulators to approve a licence for it to begin widespread training of its “full self-driving” (FSD) technology, despite an earlier indication that it would get the green light in the second quarter of 2025, people with knowledge of the matter told the Financial Times. 

The licence would be an important step towards $TSLA being able to offer semi-autonomous functionality in its vehicles in China, a development that would boost subscription revenues and help shore up its shrinking sales in the world’s largest automotive market.

The system can accelerate, steer, brake and change lanes but still requires drivers to be alert with their hands on the wheel. 

Tesla had announced in September that it planned to roll out FSD technology in China and Europe in the first quarter of 2025, subject to regulatory approval.

That ambition had already slipped and is now in greater doubt as US President Donald Trump engages in a trade war with China. Beijing imposed retaliatory tariffs on a range of American goods this month after the US put an additional 10% levy on all Chinese products. 

Chinese authorities are contemplating using the approval of Tesla’s autonomous-driving licence as a bargaining chip in trade negotiations with Trump, said two of the people with knowledge of the delay, adding that this was the main reason for the hold-up in granting the permit. 

The approval could still come soon, depending on how trade negotiations developed, one of the people added. But another said that some people at the company believed a speedy consent was unlikely unless there was “a major breakthrough or concession” in trade talks.

In June, Shanghai allowed FSD testing by 10 Tesla vehicles as a precursor to a wider rollout across China, while Tesla also struck a deal last year to use systems from tech group Baidu, which offers navigation and mapping. 

However, Musk said last month that Tesla was “in a bit of a bind” as it tried to deploy FSD in China, stuck between Beijing and Washington’s strict data security rules. 

FSD is based on a machine learning system that is fed billions of hours of video to train an algorithm to make driving decisions in real time. 

“They won’t currently allow us to transfer training video outside of China. And then the US government won’t let us do training in China,” said Musk on Tesla’s latest earnings call. “It’s a bit of a quandary.”

How Are Real World Assets Tokenized on Plume?

Tokenization turns real world assets (RWAs) – like oil, real estate, or solar energy farms – into digital tokens on the blockchain, making them easier to buy, sell, and trade.

But how does the process actually work, and can it be trusted?

1. Verify the Asset
The asset is checked for ownership, value, and legal status before being tokenized. Plume Arc simplifies this process by providing a unified platform with 50+ modular features for registering RWAs onchain.

2. Ensure Compliance
RWAs must follow financial laws. Plume Arc integrates compliance tools like KYC/KYB, custody, and on/off-ramps, ensuring assets meet regulations from day one.

3. Create Digital Tokens
The asset is converted into crypto tokens, which can be fractionalized so more people can buy them.

4. Trade and Manage Tokens
Tokens can be bought, sold, or transferred instantly. Plume Nexus Data Highway ensures accurate, real-time data flow, keeping asset information secure and up to date.

5. Hold or Redeem the Asset
Users can trade tokens, hold them, or redeem them for the real asset. Code in smart contracts automates transactions safely without needing any middle parties.

Plume makes it easier for businesses to bring RWAs onchain

Tokenization makes RWAs more accessible, but challenges like regulations, technical complexity, and liquidity have slowed adoption. Plume’s full-stack solution solves this with:

🪙 Plume Arc – A complete tokenization platform with 50+ built-in compliance and asset management tools
🪙 Plume Nexus Data Highway – A secure data infrastructure for smooth tokenization and trading
🪙 Plume RWA Chain - A scalable blockchain designed for large-scale RWA adoption

TRUMP ADMIN ASKED IRAQ TO RESUME KURDISH OIL EXPORTS QUICKLY OR FACE SANCTIONS ALONGSIDE IRAN - REUTERS

🔥🇺🇸🇮🇶The United States of America threatened, today, Friday, February 21, 2025, the federal government in Iraq with sanctions if the Kurdistan Region's oil exports are not resumed quickly.

Reuters quoted sources as saying: "The administration of President Donald Trump asked Iraq to resume (Kurdish) oil exports quickly or face sanctions alongside Iran."

The sources added, according to Reuters, that "Washington believes that Kurdish oil sales may help reduce crude prices and compensate for the decline in Iranian supplies."

Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani revealed on Tuesday that Iraq had sent a delegation from the ministry to the Kurdistan Region to agree on a mechanism for delivering the region’s oil and exporting it through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.

The Minister of Oil explained that he had contacted the Minister of Natural Resources in the region, Kamal Mohammed Saleh, to negotiate with the delegation about the mechanism for receiving and exporting oil through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.

This came a day after Iraq accelerated the expected date for the resumption of oil exports from Kurdistan, as the federal oil minister said last Monday that oil exports from the Kurdistan region could resume within just a week.

It is noteworthy that the President of the Region, Nechirvan Barzani, announced a few days ago that the resumption of shipments will likely take place next March.

Iraq exports between 400,000 and 500,000 barrels per day from fields in the north of the country, including the Kurdistan region, via the now-defunct Iraq-Turkey pipeline.

Oil Minister Hayan Abdul Ghani said earlier this month that at least 300,000 barrels per day of crude were planned to be moved once operations resumed.

In Iraqi Kurdistan, oil production ranges between about 280,000 and 300,000 barrels per day, and the regional government estimates its needs for domestic consumption - including power generation - at about 110,000 to 120,000 barrels per day.

Iraqi PM Stresses Resumption of Kurdistan’s Oil Export

Al-Sudani called on oil companies in the Kurdistan Region to immediately resume production and facilitate exports through Ceyhan port

Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani has emphasized the urgency of resuming oil production in the Kurdistan Region and restarting exports through the Turkish port of Ceyhan.
He underscored the necessity of moving forward with joint economic agreements, particularly following the recent amendments to the Federal Budget Law passed by the Iraqi Parliament.
Al-Sudani Stresses Economic Cooperation
In a statement released on Saturday, the Iraqi Prime Minister’s Office confirmed that Al-Sudani met with Kurdistan Region President Nechirvan Barzani to discuss key national issues.
The discussions focused on economic cooperation, energy policies, and the implementation of the federal government’s agenda across various sectors.
Urgent Need for Oil Exports Through Ceyhan
During the meeting, Al-Sudani stressed that restarting Kurdistan’s oil exports is a national priority, noting that its suspension has impacted Iraq’s overall economy.
He called on oil companies in the Kurdistan Region to immediately resume production and facilitate exports through Ceyhan port, ensuring economic stability and fulfilling Iraq’s financial obligations.
President Barzani Reaffirms Commitment to Coordination
For his part, President Nechirvan Barzani reiterated the Kurdistan Regional Government’s (KRG) commitment to working closely with Baghdad.
He highlighted the importance of maintaining coordination between the two governments in economic, financial, and service-related matters, which he said is essential for long-term stability and development.
Impact of Oil Export Suspension on Iraq’s Economy
Kurdistan’s oil exports have been halted since March 2023, following legal and political disputes between Baghdad, Erbil, and Ankara.
The prolonged suspension has placed significant financial strain on both the regional and federal economies. The renewed dialogue between Baghdad and Erbil is seen as a crucial step toward resolving longstanding disputes and restoring the country's vital energy sector operations.

Massive lines of tankers continue to smuggle KRG oil to Iran via Sulaimani as the Iraqi Ministry of Oil announced today that the procedures for resuming KRG oil exports through Turkey have been completed, ‘in accordance with the mechanisms specified in the budget law and its amendment, within the investment ceiling set by OPEC for Iraq’.

In its statement, the Iraqi Oil Ministry urged the KRG to transfer crude from its operational fields to the state-owned Oil Marketing Company (SOMO) to facilitate exports through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline, in accordance with agreements signed with international oil companies.

Also today Kurdistan President Nechirvan Barzani visited Baghdad, where he discussed the resumption of KRG oil exports with Iraqi PM al-Sudani. 

Meanwhile, Reuters reported that the US is pressuring Iraq to restart KRG oil exports via Turkey and curb smuggling to Iran. According to the report, the KRG informed Washington that halting production entirely is not feasible due to commitments with oil companies. The U.S. views resuming exports through Turkey as the most viable solution, not only to ease financial tensions between Erbil and Baghdad but also to counter the anticipated near-total reduction of Iranian oil exports due to sanctions. Washington want to resolve this issue to avoid prolonged diplomatic complications.

📈 China's Crude Oil Imports (2000­­–2024)

China’s crude oil imports have soared from 1.4 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2000 to a record 11.1 million bpd in 2024, reinforcing its status as the world’s largest importer with a 23% share of global imports in 2023. By 2024, over half of China's imports came from GCC countries, Iraq, and Iran, while Russia solidified its role as a key supplier, accounting for 20% of total imports.

Between 2010 and 2024, China’s crude oil imports grew at a compound annual rate (CAGR) of 6.2%. However, imports from Russia expanded at a significantly faster pace, rising by 15.1% annually, followed by the UAE (14.7%), Iraq (12.9%), Brazil (11.2%), and Oman (7.0%). In contrast, imports from Saudi Arabia saw slower growth at 4.0%, while Angola’s exports to China declined by 2.4% annually.

SULAIMANI, Kuridstan Region – Baghdad and Erbil have reached an agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region, following discussions between the Federal Ministry of Oil and the Kurdistan Regional Government’s (KRG) Ministry of Natural Resources.
In a statement, the KRG Ministy of Natural Resources announced a joint technical team has been formed to inspect and assess the Kurdistan Region oil export pipelines.
Oil exports from the Region were halted in March 2023 after a ruling by the International Chamber of Commerce ordered Turkey to stop the flow of Kurdistan’s crude through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline.
Since then, Baghdad and Erbil have struggled to reach a lasting deal, with disputes over revenue sharing and KRG’s independent oil contracts delaying the process.
The agreement comes amid ongoing negotiations over the implementation of the Federal General Budget Law, which stipulates that the KRG must deliver 400,000 barrels per day to Baghdad in exchange for its share of the national budget and salary payments of its civil servants.

ERBIL (Kurdistan24) – In a significant breakthrough, Erbil and Baghdad have reached an agreement to resume the Kurdistan Region’s oil exports, marking a step toward resolving a longstanding economic and political dispute.
As part of the agreement, a joint technical committee has been formed to inspect and assess Kurdistan’s oil export pipelines.
The Kurdistan Regional Government’s (KRG) negotiating delegation announced the agreement on Sunday, emphasizing that it was reached following extensive communications and coordination between the Iraqi Federal Oil Ministry and the Kurdistan Region’s Ministry of Natural Resources (MoNR).
According to the statement, oil exports will resume in accordance with available quantities, ensuring a gradual return to international markets.
To facilitate this process, a joint technical team was established on Sunday to conduct inspections on Kurdistan’s oil export pipelines. This step is aimed at ensuring the smooth and efficient flow of oil exports, which have been suspended for nearly two years.
“In this regard, we reaffirm our commitment to implementing the provisions of the federal general budget law,” the KRG delegation stated, signaling a commitment to the legal and regulatory framework governing oil revenues and resource management in Iraq.
The agreement follows an announcement by the Iraqi Oil Ministry on Saturday stating that all necessary procedures for resuming Kurdistan’s oil exports via Turkey’s Ceyhan port have been completed.
Read More: Iraq and Kurdistan Region Finalize Mechanism to Resume Oil Exports
This development paves the way for Kurdistan’s crude oil to re-enter international markets, stabilizing the region’s energy sector and restoring a crucial revenue stream for both Erbil and Baghdad.
The halt in Kurdistan’s oil exports, which lasted nearly two years, has had profound economic ramifications, resulting in an estimated $26 billion in losses for both Iraq and the Kurdistan Region.
The prolonged suspension also disrupted global energy markets, exacerbating supply chain challenges and economic uncertainty.
Reports by Reuters, citing eight different sources, previously suggested that the Trump administration had urged Iraq to expedite the resumption of Kurdistan’s oil exports, highlighting the geopolitical and economic significance of Kurdish crude in the broader energy landscape.
As Erbil and Baghdad move forward with the technical implementation of this agreement, attention will be focused on ensuring transparency and efficiency in oil export operations.
The resumption of exports is expected to provide much-needed financial relief to the Kurdistan Region while also strengthening the broader economic ties between the federal and regional governments.

“Rising US Oil Imports: Sectoral Winners and Losers in India’s Economy”

India’s crude oil imports from the United States surged to 218,400 barrels per day (bpd) in January 2025, a sharp increase from 70,600 bpd in December 2024. This development aligns with the observation from our earlier post*—India is strategically adjusting its import sources in response to trade deficit concerns raised by the new US administration.

Over the course of 2025, India’s crude oil and natural gas imports from the US is expected to reach $25 billion, up from $15 billion in 2024, as per recent government messaging. However, this shift is expected to come at the expense of Russian imports, as the US deploys energy-related sanctions to curb Moscow’s revenue streams and pressure them to end the war in Ukraine. For India, this transition carries substantial economic implications, particularly as Russian crude was available at a 15-20% discount to global market prices, significantly reducing our fuel bill over the past two years.

While increased crude procurement costs are likely to push up India’s fuel expenses, the direct impact on Wholesale Price Index (WPI) inflation needs to be assessed in a broader context. One silver lining is that WPI inflation has been cooling in recent months, declining from 3.43% in June 2024 to 2.31% in January 2025.

A key factor providing relief is the downward trend in food prices—which hold a 15% weight in WPI. The WPI food inflation rate has eased to 5.8% in January 2025, down from 6.9% year-on-year, driven by normalizing supply chains and improved crop yields. This could help cushion the impact of rising crude costs on overall inflation.

Analyzing major market sectors by their crude price sensitivity reveals three distinct segments. These sectors can either be producers or consumers of the WPI components, i.e. the nature of their exposure (to crude prices) differs based on their role in different supply chains.

High impact sectors, where crude or its derivatives serve as direct input material. This includes oil marketing companies, refineries, petrochemicals, and synthetic textiles which face direct margin pressure due to higher crude prices.

Medium impact sectors include industries where crude oil complements the core production process, but isn't a direct input. The cement sector and airlines are examples, where crude oil and its derivatives play an enabling role in the production process or service being offered.

Low impact sectors are those where crude primarily influences transportation costs—both for raw materials and finished goods. This encompasses metals, FMCG, pharmaceuticals, and most agricultural commodities. These sectors face limited direct exposure to crude price variations.

This analysis suggests that while higher US crude import costs will affect different sectors disproportionately, the impact on overall WPI might be moderated by strong agricultural performance expected this year. Hence, this should not have a significant bearing on the RBI’s monetary policy trajectory.

#Energy #CrudeOil #WPIInflation #IndiaEconomy #Manufacturing #Agriculture #OilAndGas #EnergySecurity #GlobalTrade #StockMarkets

Completed Keystone XL could be 'huge' for Canadian, U.S. economies: Lorne Gunter

The addition of the Keystone XL pipeline could see Canada's oil exports to the U.S. boosted by 20%, Edmonton Sun columnist Lorne Gunter told The Ezra Levant Show, something that would be “huge” for both countries' economies.

Building the Keystone XL pipeline is something Donald Trump would like to see done “NOW,” something the U.S. president wrote on his Truth Social platform. The statement got the backing from Alberta Premier Danielle Smith, who said added the countries should be exploring economic opportunities like this instead of engaging in a trade war.

On Tuesday night's episode of The Ezra Levant Show, Edmonton Sun columnist Lorne Gunter joined the show to talk about the reversal from the U.S. after it was cancelled in 2020 during the early days of the Biden administration.

Looking at what the completion of this project could mean for Canada's economy, Lorne said “it's huge.”

“I'd love to see it; 830,000 extra barrels a day to the United States,” he added. “It would increase our exports to the U.S. — one pipeline — would increase our exports to the United States by nearly 20%.”

Last week, I led a high-level delegation to the Liberty Free Trade Zone in Akwa Ibom State to inspect the APPL Green Hydrogen and Green Methanol Project—a landmark initiative in Nigeria’s renewable energy drive.

This visit reaffirms the Federal Government’s commitment to advancing renewable energy, industrialization, and technology-driven innovation as key drivers of economic growth.

As the global energy landscape shifts towards cleaner alternatives, investments in green hydrogen and green methanol production are positioning Nigeria at the forefront of green energy innovation.

The integration of science and technology in this sector will not only drive industrial development but also create jobs, attract foreign investment, and strengthen Nigeria’s standing in the global energy market.

During our visit, we received a comprehensive technical briefing, conducted a thorough site inspection, and engaged in high-level strategic discussions on optimizing innovation for industrial growth.

Our primary objective is to ensure that this project aligns with national priorities, particularly in building a robust research and development ecosystem that drives sustainable energy solutions.

The success of transformative projects like this requires strong collaboration between the public and private sectors, and I am confident that our engagements will further strengthen this partnership.

Much like the Industrial Revolution reshaped economies in the past, we are now on the brink of a Renewable Energy Revolution—and Nigeria must take the lead.

As we move forward, the Federal Ministry of Innovation, Science, and Technology remains committed to supporting groundbreaking projects that will establish Nigeria as a global leader in renewable energy and industrial innovation.

Basis Trade Vaults are coming with @Lombard_Finance and @ether_fi.

The Idea
Bitcoin is digital gold, Ethereum is digital oil. They're fundamental assets yet, they often sit idle missing yield. In 2023/24, basis trading and LSTs surged in popularity; unlocking new layers of yield. Now we take it one step further.

Enter basis trading vaults. Idle LSTs/LRTs are combined with staking rewards and a delta=1 basis trade. Unlike traditional basis strategies that hedge out price movements, these vaults keep full exposure to BTC and ETH; meaning you still benefit from price appreciation while earning yield from funding spreads.

The Strategy
A basis trade exploits the difference between spot and perpetual futures prices. The vault mechanics are straightforward:
➤ Deposit. Provide LBTC or weETH as collateral.
➤ Leverage & Hedge. Borrow stablecoins, buy more LBTC/weETH (Derive secret sauce), and short perps to lock in the basis spread.
➤ Earn. Collect staking rewards, funding rate differentials, and amplified points from atomic execution.

What if the market moves against me?
The strategy stays hedged. Holding 2 LBTC or weETH against a $100k debt stays safe even if BTC/ETH 100x’s or drops 90%. Gains on one leg offset losses on the other; price is a non-issue. The only pricing risk is a depeg.

What if funding flips or borrowing costs spike? 
If perp funding turns negative or stablecoin borrow rates rise, the system automatically reduces leverage to avoid prolonged negative carry.

Are there any liquidity risks?
In cases of low spot or perp liquidity, the vault may take longer to exit positions, potentially resulting in brief periods of negative funding.

The Yield
➤ Perp Funding (est. 10-20%) – Borrow Rate (5-10%) = Basis Yield
➤ Leveraged LBTC & weETH Staking + Points = Additional APR
➤ Compounded, this turns idle BTC & ETH into a more efficient yield engine.

Basis trading has long been a staple in TradFi, generating steady, predictable returns by capturing spreads between spot and futures markets. Now, with yield-bearing collateral like LSTs and LRTs, the strategy is being automated for DeFi.

Institutions are taking note. As the market matures, structured, delta-neutral strategies are moving from niche to necessity. More to follow.

APIKUR spokesperson Myles Caggins told Zoom News the group’s eight member companies are ready to resume oil exports in the Kurdistan Region once they receive guarantees for payment and a plan to settle outstanding debts.

"The APIKUR spokesperson went on to detail that the "APIKUR member companies have not received any outreach to establish new agreements that provide surety of payment for past and future exports consistent with our existing contractual legal and commercial terms.”

🔹 A surety in payments refers to a person or entity that guarantees the payment of a debt or obligation if the primary party responsible for the payment fails to fulfill their obligation. The surety provides financial security to the creditor, ensuring that the payment will be made even if the debtor defaults. 🔻 
🔸 A Surety Bond - A guarantee issued by a third party (such as an insurance company or bank) to ensure that a contractual obligation, such as a payment, will be met.
🔸 A Guarantor - An individual or company that agrees to cover the debt if the primary borrower defaults.

🔹 A surety in payments is a legally binding agreement. When a person or entity (the surety) agrees to guarantee the payment obligations of another party (the principal), they are legally obligated to fulfill the payment if the principal defaults. The terms of the surety agreement are typically outlined in a contract, which defines the responsibilities of the principal, the surety, and the creditor (the beneficiary). If the principal fails to meet their obligations, the creditor can legally enforce the surety's commitment to pay.

Shafaq News/ A delegation from the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) arrived in Baghdad for talks on resuming oil exports via Turkiye’s Ceyhan pipeline, informed sources revealed on Sunday.
“Representatives from the KRG’s Ministry of Natural Resources are meeting with officials at the Federal Ministry of Oil to address outstanding issues, including the restart of oil exports from the Region’s fields and operational concerns of oil companies,” one source told Shafaq News.
Another source noted that the meeting, initially scheduled for Tuesday, was moved up due to recent developments but declined to provide further details.
The discussions follow an invitation from the Federal Ministry of Oil to international oil companies operating under the Association of the Petroleum Industry of Kurdistan (APIKUR) and the KRG’s Ministry of Natural Resources to attend a meeting in Baghdad on March 4, 2025.

Here's a list of what price increases you can expect from Trump's tariffs: 

1. Crude Oil & Petroleum Products – Canada is the largest supplier of crude oil to the U.S., accounting for around half of total U.S. oil imports.

2. Natural Gas – A major energy source for heating and electricity, with extensive pipeline networks connecting the two countries.

3. Automobiles & Auto Parts – Canada is a key supplier of vehicles and components, supporting the North American auto industry.

4. Electricity – Some U.S. regions, especially in the Northeast and Midwest, import significant amounts of hydroelectric power from Canada.

5. Lumber & Wood Products – Canadian softwood lumber is essential for U.S. construction and homebuilding.

6. Aluminum & Steel – Canada is one of the largest suppliers of aluminum and steel, used in manufacturing, construction, and defense industries.

7. Agricultural Products – Wheat, canola, beef, pork, and seafood (especially lobster and salmon) are major food imports.

8. Minerals & Metals – Canada supplies key minerals like potash (used in fertilizers), uranium (for nuclear power), and nickel (for batteries and stainless steel).

End of week thoughts: President Trump’s tariff tango keeps the market guessing on which foot to dance.

OPEC+ trusted its oil balance enough to initiate the unwinding of voluntary cuts, or alternatively, it could be argued that OPEC+ sent an olive branch to President Trump to show it was doing its part, without losing face, in helping to bring the oil price down. Take your pick; it does not matter as the small incremental volume to be reinstated in the coming months is irrelevant in the larger scheme of things, given the gross non-compliance by member countries like the UAE or Iraq. The global oil balance is long in 2025, so the optics of OPEC+’s decision wrong-footing expectations were inevitably going to be treated as price-negative from a sentiment point of view. ICE Brent briefly traded under $69/bbl as a result. That should tell you something. Today’s comments by Russian Deputy Prime Minister Novak about OPEC+ potentially reducing output to address any “imbalance” in the future to shore up sentiment fell on deaf ears.

President Trump’s tariff tango kept the market guessing on which foot to dance. Aggressive US economic and foreign policy offset each other in terms of oil price impact this week. On the one hand, the imposition of tariffs on Canada and Mexico seems to be now complicated by the provisions of the USMCA trade accord, and the timeline is consistently shifting it seems, as is what will fall under tariffs. Add to that President Trump touted the possibility of reciprocal tariffs being introduced as soon as today, and you have bearish cocktail for price. On the other hand, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent provided bullish fodder, and he did not mince his words indicating the US would be prepared to reduce Iranian crude oil exports to a trickle and cripple Iran’s economy under a maximum pressure policy – hard to say if the US is really going ‘all-in’ or is this the usual waiving of the big stick again to advance an alternative agenda. Mr Bessent's comments managed to pull Brent out from the $60 handle doldrums, sending the front-month ICE contract towards $71.50/bbl.

However, the end-of-week price action would not have been complete without President Putin. Headlines emerged today indicating that Russia would be prepared to talk about a temporary truce in the Ukraine War if there was progress towards a final peace settlement. Flat price fell towards $70.25/bbl at the time of writing. For all the gyrations in the flat price this week, prompt Brent time-spreads have not collapsed and are holding at 50 cents, which should provide OPEC with some comfort that the wheels have not yet come off the fundamental cart. With steady spreads, the curve is trying to find a new level amidst the general uncertainty, so expect more parallel shifts in the curve until market sentiment settles, assuming it can settle amidst the Trump whirlwind.

Here's a summary of the key developments in the oil and gas industry over the past week: 

U.S. Policy and Market Impacts

Natural Gas Exports: In Port Sulphur, Louisiana, Interior Secretary Doug Burgum and Energy Secretary Chris Wright underscored the administration's support for expanding natural gas exports. They criticized previous climate policies and highlighted plans for an $18 billion expansion by Venture Global to export LNG to Europe and Asia. ​https://t.co/Yjo5dNWu7n

Oil Prices and Economic Concerns: President Trump's efforts to lower energy prices, including pressuring OPEC to increase oil production, have led to a drop in oil prices. This decline poses challenges for Texas oil producers, potentially leading to job losses and economic downturns in the region. Additionally, tariffs on steel have increased costs for the oil industry, exacerbating the situation. ​https://t.co/ICP2xpDBYB

Corporate Movements

Hedge Fund Positioning: Elliott Management has taken a €670 million short position in TotalEnergies, amounting to 0.52% of the company's stock. This move follows Elliott's investment in BP, where it owns nearly 5% and is advocating for a greater focus on oil and gas. Despite TotalEnergies' strong performance and moderate stance on energy transition, the sizable short position is notable. ​https://t.co/jbbfydWdSR

Geopolitical Events

Infrastructure Attacks: Russian forces targeted Ukraine's energy infrastructure, damaging natural gas production facilities owned by Naftogaz. The attacks affected multiple regions, prompting efforts to stabilize power and gas supplies. This escalation underscores the vulnerability of energy infrastructure in conflict zones. ​https://t.co/93LJeoBoMB

Industry Outlook

Net-Zero Emissions Projections: A survey by Bain and Company reveals that nearly half of energy and natural resources executives now predict that net-zero emissions won't be achieved until 2070 or later, up from 32% last year. Rising costs, financial constraints, and a shift towards prioritizing returns over environmental investments contribute to this growing pessimism. ​https://t.co/cC6jQOwtxr

Regulatory Developments

North Sea Drilling Ban: The UK government has confirmed a ban on new drilling licenses in the North Sea as part of its strategy to transition to cleaner energy. An eight-week consultation will address concerns over potential job losses and energy security. The move aligns with the UK's commitment to achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, making it the first major G7 oil producer to halt new oil and gas licensing. ​https://t.co/JQ6FMw326u

Recent Developments in the Oil and Gas Industry

What's Trump's real plan for Alberta's oilsands?

Premier Smith pointed out that President Trump's proposed 10% tariffs on Canadian energy instead of 25% like other goods signifies the critical nature of Canadian oil for the United States.

The president previously floated the idea of reviving the Keystone XL pipeline project that was cancelled by the Biden administration. However President Trump has also repeatedly threatened to impose a 10% tariff on Canadian oil as well, although he walked back the threat yesterday.

@Dfildebrandt commented on the back-and-forth nature of Trump's messaging surrounding Canadian energy and what his real plans could be.

"I'm not sure there is understanding it," he said. "There's a 'mad dog' theory of Trump, that he's just throwing us off and softening us up, but I'm not seeing any strategy in this," he added.

Speaking specifically on Trump's tariff threats on Canadian oil, Fildebrandt was perplexed by Trump's thought process.

"It's not good for American refineries, it's not good for American energy independence...it doesn't square with Keystone XL, I'm just not seeing any strategy here," he said.

President Trump announced on Thursday that he would be scaling back some tariffs for Canada until at least April 2.

🔥Iraq tells US: Stopping Iranian gas imports will cause electricity system to collapse🔥

On Sunday, the head of the Finance Committee in the Iraqi Parliament, Atwan Al-Atwani, sent a letter to the US government stating that stopping the import of gas from Iran will cause the collapse of the electricity grid system during the coming summer in Iraq, indicating the need to extend the exemptions granted to Iraq in this regard after they were officially stopped by the administration of US President Donald Trump.

This came during Al-Atwani's meeting with the US Ambassador to Iraq, Daniel Rubinstein, and the accompanying delegation, according to the MP's media office.

The head of the Parliamentary Finance Committee stressed the importance of this visit at this sensitive time, and stressed the need for continuous communication to correct the course of Iraqi-American relations.

The statement added that the meeting focused on discussing the US sanctions file and their impact on the electricity sector, especially in light of talk about the expiration of the deadline for Iraq to be exempted from importing Iranian gas.

The statement also indicated that Al-Atwani conveyed an important message to the US ambassador to his country's government, stating that stopping gas imports would have disastrous consequences for the Iraqi people, especially in the summer, as it would cause the collapse of the national electricity system, due to the lack of any alternatives at the present time.

Al-Atwani said during the meeting that the Iraqi government is serious about achieving energy independence through several promising projects related to investing in associated gas, for the purpose of using it in generating electricity and achieving self-sufficiency, but these projects will enter service in the coming years.

Al-Atwani also called on the US administration to review the policy of pressure exerted by the US Treasury on the financial and banking sector in Iraq by imposing continuous sanctions on local banks.

He pointed out that Iraq has achieved a qualitative shift in the policy of compliance and financial transfers, and despite that, we are surprised by collective sanctions targeting Iraqi banks without prior warning and without any declared justification or even notifying the Central Bank of Iraq about that, and this has created a major problem for us and affected the work and activity of the banking sector.

In turn, the US Ambassador expressed his understanding of what Al-Atwani had raised during the meeting regarding the energy and banking sanctions files, and promised to convey these messages to his country's government in the hope of finding permanent treatments and solutions that would achieve the interests of the two friendly peoples, noting that the import of natural gas is, until now, outside the sanctions system, according to the statement.

In this episode of the Energy News Beat Daily Standup, the host, Stuart Turley discusses key topics including the collapse of the Green Revolution, the UK’s complex stance on oil and gas exploration, and the potential failure of the UK’s AI pivot due to resource and industrial challenges. He also covers the merger of Whitecap and Verdin to create a major Canadian oil producer and highlights the growing importance of natural gas as America’s top export, particularly under President Trump’s trade rebalancing. Turley emphasizes the need for strategic investments in energy and training to navigate these evolving challenges.

Donnie T and his Three-wheeled bike

Who’s afraid of the petulant tyke?  
It’s Donnie T., on his three-wheeled bike.  
He huffs and he puffs, red tie askew,  
Throwing his tantrums in red, white, and blue.  

"Tariffs will win!" he shouts to the wind,  
But allies just laugh, the world chagrinned.  
Slapping on duties like stickers on toys,  
As if bluster alone could silence the noise.  

He tweets in the night, caps locked tight,  
"Sad!" or "Fake News!"—it’s quite the sight.  
Grumpy and gruff, yet oddly theatrical,  
A presidency that feels...almost satirical.  

"China will bend! Europe will pay!"  
But deals unravel day after day.  
Bullied and sulking, he scrawls with his pen,  
Rewriting his loss as some masterstroke win.  

The infantile roar, the toddler-like pout,  
The ego unchecked, forever in doubt.  
He builds his walls, he burns each bridge,  
A chaos-monger atop his ridge.  

But here’s the thing, Donnie boy:  
The world isn’t your personal toy.  
Your temper tantrums won’t bend their knees,  
Nor will your bluster tame the seas.  

So let him rage, this Pilin' brat,  
Demanding a crown and a gilded hat.  
His wake-up call’s a matter of time—  
History’s pen will finish this rhyme.
