Wind Financial Morning Post: May 7, 2025

China's financial markets opened on a positive note, with high-level Sino-US trade talks drawing significant attention. Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng is set to meet U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen during his visit to Switzerland. The Ministry of Commerce stated that China has agreed to engage in dialogues with the U.S. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs emphasized the necessity for the U.S. to stop exerting pressure tactics.

Yellen expressed optimism over potential progress in trade negotiations in the coming weeks and remarked on the unsustainable nature of the 145% tariffs imposed on Chinese goods during the Trump administration. Additionally, Chinese A-share listed companies reported robust first-quarter results, with 75.46% achieving profitability—showcasing the resilience of China's economy.

On the domestic macroeconomic front, Finance Minister Lan Fo'an highlighted that China is committed to proactive macroeconomic policies to meet its 2025 growth target of approximately 5%. However, the Caixin China Services PMI in April fell to a seven-month low, signaling a slowdown in business expansion. Data from the State Taxation Administration revealed accelerated investment in engineering projects in the first quarter, and the May Day holiday saw domestic tourists' total spending, grow by 6.4% year-on-year, with 314 million domestic tourism trips—a 6.4% increase compared to the previous year.

In financial policy updates, the State Council's Information Office announced a forthcoming press conference to outline a comprehensive financial policy package aimed at stabilizing market expectations. Vice Governor of the PBOC, Xuan Changneng, stated that the country is advancing legislation on deposit insurance law to strengthen its core deposit insurance functions.

In domestic economic developments, first-quarter earnings of A-share listed companies reflected a strong start, with 75.46% of enterprises reporting profits, underscoring the country's economic momentum. This aligns with China's 2025 GDP growth target of around 5%, as reiterated by Minister of Finance Liu Kun, who also pledged to further open China's economy to the global market.

A-share markets saw significant upward momentum on the first trading day after the May Day holiday. The SSE Index rose 1.13%, closing at 3,395 points, while the Shenzhen Component Index gained 1.84%, and the ChiNext Index advanced 1.97%. The broader Wind All China Index surged by 1.62%. Total market turnover expanded to 1.36 trillion yuan, with nearly 5,000 stocks seeing gains. Chinese bond markets were also active, though the main treasury bond futures contracts saw mixed movements: the 10-year bond futures declined by 0.16%, while the 5-year bond futures slipped 0.09%.

Russia is laundering its oil through Indonesia’s gray zone.

According to Ukraine’s Foreign Intelligence Service, the port of Karimun—a free trade zone outside Indonesian jurisdiction—has become Moscow’s main transshipment hub in 2025.

Here’s how the scheme works:
▪️ Russian oil products are blended with imports from other countries, rebranded as “Indonesian”
▪️ This allows sanctioned fuel to be legally sold to Singapore, Malaysia, and China
▪️ The trade is handled by shell companies with constantly changing names

Since January, shipments from Russia’s Ust-Luga port to Karimun include:
– 590,000 tons of fuel oil
– 217,000 tons of diesel
– 50,000 tons of crude oil

At least three tankers under EU and UK sanctions delivered cargo there between March and April. This is how Russia dodges restrictions—one renamed ship at a time.

Gas and imports combined for 21 GWh in this time period.

📈 The Evolution of Saudi Arabia’s Trade with China, the EU, and the U.S.

China has emerged as Saudi Arabia’s largest trading partner and the world’s leading importer of crude oil, while Saudi Arabia stands as China’s primary trade partner in the Middle East and its second-largest global crude oil supplier. In 2024, bilateral trade between the two countries reached $107 billion—surpassing Saudi Arabia’s combined trade with the European Union ($75 billion) and the United States ($26 billion). This shift underscores a broader realignment of Saudi Arabia’s economic ties toward Asia, particularly in the context of China’s growing influence in global energy markets.

From 2000 to 2024, Saudi-China trade expanded at a remarkable 15.9% compound annual growth rate (CAGR), soaring from just $3.1 billion to $107 billion. Over the same period, trade with the EU grew at a 4.5% CAGR (from $26 billion to $75 billion), while trade with the U.S. increased at a modest 1.0% CAGR (from $21 billion to $26 billion). These figures highlight China’s rapidly rising share in Saudi Arabia’s global trade portfolio.

#SaudiArabia #USA #EU #China #trade #energy #oil

🚨BARZANI MEETING IN DC “A SIGNIFICANT VISIT”

💥 build an enduring partnership grounded in security, sovereignty, and shared prosperity

Timmerman believes that President Trump could favor Erbil over Baghdad in future disputes—especially in matters of oil exports and regional influence. “if I were to make a guess, I would say that president Trump would come out on the side of Erbil over Baghdad [...] Right now, Baghdad is being, has been infiltrated for years and years by Tehran, by the Iranian regime, so that's going to be the point of conflict.”

He cited efforts to reopen the Ceyhan pipeline for Kurdish oil exports to Europe via Turkey as a test case for U.S.-Kurdish cooperation. “[Prime Minister] Barzani has very good relations with the Turkish government, and that will help. And President Trump has very good personal relationships with President Erdogan. So I think that's the way that they would both like to go [...] but then they would have to get the agreement of Baghdad.”

The broader vision Timmerman laid out involves integrating the Kurdistan Region into a regional defense network against Iranian expansionism. While he acknowledged political constraints due to Iraq's federal structure, he stressed that long-term U.S. interests lie in seeing a unified, professional Peshmerga army and a Kurdish government that can contribute to collective regional security.

“I think the United States would like to see the Peshmerga as a united force, as a single force, not as party militias, but as a single government force, to express the will of the KRG government as a whole,” he said.

“I think also, they would like to see a, you know, a global or I should say a regional, air defense system. I'm not sure that they're ready yet to bring Kurdistan into that because of the relationship with Baghdad. Again, Baghdad is infiltrated by the Iranian regime, and that is a severe problem. But I think, ultimately, that would be the goal to see, the KRG as part of a regional alliance to defend the interests of freedom-loving countries against the Iranian regime,” he added.

Asked whether the Kurdistan Region could realistically seal its borders from Iranian infiltration, Timmerman responded with guarded optimism: “I hope your Prime Minister will ask for assistance from Washington to help seal the borders with Iran, so the Iranians can no longer infiltrate, can penetrate, and can do damage to, your citizens, inside the Kurdish region.”

Timmerman emphasized that peace and stability in Kurdistan are not merely regional concerns but strategic priorities for the United States. He noted that the Kurdish Region, as part of Iraq, is demonstrating that a moderate, non-radical, pro-Western polity can exist in the Middle East, adding that it is in America's interest to ensure that this continues.

For Kenneth R. Timmerman, the choice is clear: reinforce the U.S.-Kurdistan alliance, resist Iranian encroachment, and build an enduring partnership grounded in security, sovereignty, and shared prosperity.

📈 EU Crude Oil Imports: Major Shifts Post-Russia Sanctions (2021–2024)

EU sanctions on Russia, triggered by the 2022 Ukraine invasion, slashed EU crude oil imports from Russia by 89% (2.30 Mb/d to 0.26 Mb/d) from 2021 to 2024. The Americas and Africa significantly offset this decline: U.S. imports surged 88% (0.75 Mb/d to 1.40 Mb/d), Brazil 157% (0.18 Mb/d to 0.45 Mb/d), Guyana 1626% (0.02 Mb/d to 0.33 Mb/d), and Angola 403% (0.04 Mb/d to 0.18 Mb/d). Norway’s exports grew 36% (0.81 Mb/d to 1.10 Mb/d), Saudi Arabia 40% (0.47 Mb/d to 0.66 Mb/d), and Kazakhstan 48% (0.68 Mb/d to 1.00 Mb/d). This shift underscores a profound reconfiguration of EU oil supply chains.

99% of strategies work if YOU can follow them

2- I wasted 2 years strategy hopping before i realized this
Trade ONE setup on ONE timeframe

Master it completely before you add anything else

3-Be a risk manager FIRST, trader second

Soon as i started treating myself as the risk department, everything changed

No trade happens without mapping out risk first.

4- Trading is boring when done right

If you're feeling an adrenaline rush, you're gambling not trading

5- Keep a trading journal
Review it weekly and be brutally honest with yourself

All my breakthroughs came from seeing my own patterns

6- You need to be uncomfortable

Comfort breeds laziness

Working 2 jobs, going to college, and trading was probably the best decision I could have made.

The ones who actually implement will be the ones posting their success stories next year

Nigeria Customs Service Pledges Support for Renewable Energy Trade

…Marks One Year of Advance Ruling Implementation

The Nigeria Customs Service (NCS) has reaffirmed its commitment to promoting seamless and sustainable trade operations, with a renewed focus on facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies.

The Comptroller-General of Customs (CGC), Adewale Adeniyi, who was represented by Deputy Comptroller-General of Customs (DCG) Caroline Niagwan, in charge of the Tariff and Trade Department, made the pledge in Lagos on Monday, 19 May 2025, during the 2025 edition of the NCS Trade Facilitation Stakeholder Consultative Forum, which also commemorated one year anniversary of the Advance Ruling Programme.

Held under the theme “Trade Facilitation Measures for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Technologies,” the forum brought together key industry stakeholders, development partners, and government officials to explore Customs’ evolving role in supporting Nigeria’s transition to a low-carbon economy.

Delivering the keynote address, DCG Caroline Niagwan described trade facilitation as central to Customs’ contribution to national development and global sustainability efforts.

“With the increasing volume of global trade, it has become imperative for Customs administrations to adopt mechanisms that support the seamless flow of legitimate trade. Such mechanisms are essential not only for sustaining international commerce but also for enabling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to benefit from cross-border trade,” said DCG Niagwan.

She highlighted key initiatives introduced by the NCS to simplify and modernise Customs operations, including the Unified Customs Management System (UCMS), codenamed B’Odogwu, the Advance Ruling System, and the Authorised Economic Operator (AEO) Programme.

On Nigeria’s environmental obligations, the DCG reiterated the NCS’s support for the Green Customs Initiative and multilateral environmental agreements such as the Montreal Protocol and the Paris Agreement.

“The Nigeria Customs Service plays a pivotal role in supporting these national objectives by facilitating the importation of renewable energy technologies and implementing fiscal measures that promote a shift away from fossil fuels, with the ultimate goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060,” she stated.

As part of the Advance Ruling Programme anniversary celebration, the DCG reaffirmed the Service’s commitment to fostering efficient, secure, and sustainable trade operations.

A key highlight of the event was the official launch of the Handbook on Import and Export Procedures for Renewable Energy and Energy-Efficient Technologies, which aims to provide guidance to stakeholders and traders on Customs processes applicable to clean energy equipment.

In a goodwill message, Markus Wagner, Country Director for Nigeria and ECOWAS at GIZ, represented by Duke Benjamin, commended the NCS for its strategic foresight. He remarked that the initiative underscores the critical role of Customs in advancing Nigeria’s renewable energy aspirations. “Today’s launch represents another significant step towards improving the ease of doing business in Nigeria,” he added.

Stakeholders present at the forum also shared testimonials on the positive impact of the Advance Ruling Programme, applauding the NCS for its innovation and responsiveness to the trading community's needs.

Iraq’s Oil Pivot Signals More Than Just a Supply Cut

Iraq’s oil exports to the U.S. have plunged—from 229K bpd (May 10) to just 85K bpd last week. This steep drop aligns with Iraq’s compliance with OPEC+ cuts but also signals deeper shifts.

🚨 Baghdad nullified $110B in Kurdish-U.S. energy deals

🚧 Pipeline exports via Turkey remain blocked

📉 IMF projects weaker current account for Iraq in 2025

💱 Pressure mounts on the Iraqi dinar amid falling USD inflows

Historically, the U.S. took 9.4% of Iraq’s oil. By April 2025? Just 4.64%. The bulk now flows to India and China, as Iraq leans into non-dollar trade—fueling de-dollarization narratives.

This isn’t just a supply issue. It’s a geopolitical reset.
As internal disputes between Baghdad and Kurdistan deepen, Iraq’s oil strategy is shifting—away from the West and toward Asia. This not only alters trade balances but may chip away at USD dominance in global energy markets.

IEA projects global oil demand to slow in H2 2025, compounding Iraq’s revenue concerns. The dinar’s stability and Iraq’s long-term trade alliances now hang in the balance.

An often overlooked edge is: Identifying Trade Duration. 

The lion’s share of my PnL has come from positions held over multiple weeks.

I see too many people emulating a scalping style stemming largely from risk aversion rather than a desire to maximize EV.

Others hold positions so long they become “investors” rather than traders.

Ask yourself what trade duration has made you the most money, but also what trade duration you have the highest hit rate with.

Even amongst new pair memes, some narratives could take days or weeks to play out rather than an afternoon.

You should question how long you expect a trade will take to play out before you even enter the position.

Far too often traders panic about intraday movements when their intention was to hold for a week +.

Europe’s green agenda is hitting a wall — and it’s painted in soy, beef, and palm oil.

The stakes? This law targets the 10% of global deforestation tied to EU demand.

The pushback? “Impossible to implement,” “disproportionate,” and “too costly.”

And behind the green language? Billions in commodity flows and a fight over who gets checked — and who gets a pass.

The Flin Flon Bombers are pleased to announce that graduating forward Keefe Gruener has committed to Brock University (U-Sports).

Gruener was acquired at the 2024 CJHL Trade Deadline from the AJHL’s Fort McMurray Oil Barons and had an immediate impact which saw the Bombers reach the league final for a third season in a row. 

Heading into his final season of junior hockey, Keefe was named an alternate captain. The product of Winnipeg, Manitoba had a breakout season by scoring 34 goals and adding 28 assists in just 47 games. Gruener’s 34 goals was second among all SJHL players and his 1.32 points-per-game-average was sixth. In 12 playoff games, Keefe put up 9 points.

Not only did Gruener contribute on the scoresheet, he was one of the SJHL’s top penalty killers and had one of the league’s highest faceoff percentages at 65%.

The Brock University Badgers compete in the Ontario University Athletics Conference and finished the 2024-2025 season with a 12-11-5 record. Former Bomber Rylan Thiessen is currently a Badger and will be heading into his fourth season with the program.

The strategy that Brad is calling for (Tesla to trade in it's own stock) is not only (extremely) risky from an investment perspective, it is (extremely) risky - foolhardingly so - from a legal perspective. 
To understand the legal jeopardy Tesla would face, here is Grok's very clear conclusion in it's analysis of the strategy:
"Conclusion:
A Nasdaq-listed company can legally repurchase its shares under strict conditions (Rule 10b-18) and sell shares if compliant with registration and antifraud rules. However, actively trading its own stock to exploit dips and highs risks violating insider trading and market manipulation laws, especially if MNPI is involved or the activity misleads investors. Legal counsel and adherence to SEC regulations are critical to avoid liability."
If you are interested in the detailed analysis, here is the full Grok prompt and response.  https://t.co/iDhYcFK4tl
However, what Grok does NOT analyze is the prospect of a full scale class action suit being brought by aggresive law firms on almost any/every trade conducted by the company (even those, and especially those, that make profits!) There is a reason that companies stick to buying their own shares strictly under the SEC Rule 10b-18 share buy back safe harbor, and almost never because they wish to "buy the dip". That form of trading almost automatically implies MNPI, even when none is involved! This is why Directors and Senior Managers try to only buy or sell shares according to a published plan under safe harbor rules. 
This is a really bad idea: the only consolation is that it would NEVER be approved by the Legal Counsel or the Board of Directors.

Zano’s price is driven by real-world usage. Every private peer-to-peer (P2P) transaction on the network—monetary or non-monetary assets—requires Zano as gas. As more people around the world embrace private trade, demand for Zano rises. 

Once daily transaction volume reaches 144,000, Zano’s supply becomes deflationary—meaning fewer coins are available over time. The combination of increasing demand and decreasing supply creates upward pressure on price.

Zano is more than just a deflationary asset. It is the foundation of a sovereign, decentralized, and private economy. With Zano, you can:

1. Use the world’s first private algorithmic stablecoin — $fUSD
 
Preserve your privacy while rejecting US Treasury-backed stablecoins. $fUSD is overcollateralized by Zano, not by fiat or central banks, making it the first stablecoin aligned with freedom rather than financial surveillance.

2. Make transparent blockchains private
 
Trustlessly bridge Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Bitcoin Cash—blockchains representing over $2.3 trillion in market cap—to Zano using Confidential Layer, turning them into truly private assets.

3. Buy and sell anywhere with privacy
 
Trade goods and services globally without third parties. Zano Bay enables end-to-end encrypted commerce directly on the blockchain—no middlemen, no exposure.

4. Mint and use private NFTs
 
Create and trade non-fungible tokens without compromising privacy. See it in action at obscura(dot)art.

5. Accept Zano for your business
 
Start taking Zano easily through zano(dot)cash, a privacy-first solution for merchants.

6. Tokenize and privately trade any asset
 
From real estate to collectibles, tokenize and exchange anything without banks, brokers, or surveillance. Zano’s peer-to-peer exchange enables direct, private value transfer.

Zano is not a speculative token. It’s the infrastructure for a new economic model—voluntary, decentralized, and private. It is the answer to CBDCs/Stablecoins as backdoor CBDCs. 

As usage grows, so does value. Exit surveillance finance and empower privacy with Zano.

The Machine Economy Is Here ▪️ $PEAQ ▪️ 

Imagine a world where your car can pay for its own charging, your home appliances trade energy with your neighbor’s solar panels

And a fleet of delivery drones organize themselves to avoid traffic and reduce emissions 
All without human intervention.

It might sound futuristic, but we’re already taking the first steps into that world. 

The real shift isn’t just about machines becoming smarter. 

It’s about them becoming economically active, able to make decisions, own value, and participate in the systems that shape our lives.  

This transformation is about how we, as people, interact with the world around us.

Up until now, most of the “smart” devices we use — phones, appliances, vehicles — are still deeply dependent on centralized systems. 

They collect our data, send it to corporations, and leave us with little control or benefit. 

But what if machines could act on their own — earning, spending, and collaborating with each other, just like people do in an economy ?

A world where devices don’t just serve us, but actively participate in building smarter, fairer systems around us.

That’s where @peaq comes in.  $PEAQ
Think of it as the digital foundation for this new kind of machine-powered society 

A kind of Internet for machines, but with built-in trust and economic logic. 

peaq allows machines — whether it’s a car, a robot, or a sensor 

To have a digital identity, to earn money for the work they do, and to spend or invest that income without needing a middleman.  

It’s not about replacing people. It’s about freeing up possibilities:

🔹Giving small communities the power to manage local energy with smart meters and solar panels.

🔹Enabling cities to run smoother with autonomous maintenance systems.

🔹Creating entirely new forms of income and collaboration between humans and machines.

These aren’t theoretical use cases — they’re already being built today with peaq, in areas like energy, mobility, and logistics.  
In the past, infrastructure was something only large companies and governments could control. 

With peaq’s decentralized approach, the model is flipped: machines become accessible tools anyone can plug into

And the benefits don’t go to a few platforms — they flow directly to the people and communities who participate. 
 The implications are enormous. 

Machines can now co-own the services they provide, share the profits, and evolve over time with the help of AI. 
We’re heading into a future where economic activity isn’t limited to humans, and where the systems we rely on become smarter, fairer, and more resilient 

Because they’re built by all of us, for all of us.  

And at the heart of this transformation is a network designed for this exact moment — peaq: the digital soil in which the machine economy will grow.

India’s Oil Imports From Russia Hit 10-Month High

New Delhi ramped up crude oil imports from Moscow to 1.96mn barrels per day in May - the highest level in 10 months - thanks to deep discounts on offer, according to global shipping tracker Kpler.

With India importing around 5.1mn barrels per day in total last month, Russia alone accounted for over 38% of that, making it India’s top oil supplier by far and proving key in keeping fuel prices stable for millions.

Iraq held second place, supplying 1.2mn barrels per day.

ARGENTINA BOOSTS OIL EXPORTS WITH NEW PIPELINE INAUGURATION

Argentina has inaugurated a critical pipeline to enhance oil exports from the Vaca Muerta basin, increasing shipments by 26% despite falling global prices.

The $1.4 billion privately funded project, the largest in 20 years, spans 525 kilometers from Neuquén to Puerto Rosales, operated by Oldelval.

It will transport 540,000 barrels daily, up from 225,000, adding $8 billion annually to exports.

The pipeline, built by Techint-Sacde and OPS, connects to storage at Puerto Rosales (Otamerica) and Puerto Galván (Trafigura).

This infrastructure eliminates costly truck transport, previously six times more expensive, and supports Argentina’s goal of exporting 1 million barrels daily by 2030.

Russia’s war economy is taking a direct hit as EU sanctions tighten the noose on Putin’s oil exports. 👇👇

1. Russian crude exports plummeted 29% in one week — one of the steepest drops since the Ukraine war began.

<My personal thoughts on natural gas>

It's true that LNG feed gas has been weak recently due to short-term maintenance, but that doesn't matter and won't last long.

The key is the year-end LNG ramp up. US LNG exports, which have already been on the rise for several years, will once again significantly increase towards the end of the year.

During this injection season, traders are bound to have an upside bias and will need to build much more stocks than normal. 

This is because everyone is anticipating the structural demand drivers, leaving the market extremely vulnerable to winter weather variability.

We don't need 5-year avg stocks, we need more than that. Nevertheless we are starting the beginning of the cooling demand season with a pretty good weather model.

L48 production remains stagnant. As the US shale basins are being gasified, we are unlikely to see a dramatic decline in Permian associated gas production despite lower oil prices, but we are certain to see slower growth than consensus at the start of the year.

Even in the traditional gas producing plays (Appalachian, Haynesville), we are seeing pretty good discipline. This is a huge opportunity for commodity funds or traders. 

You can buy producer stocks like $AR and $EQT to gain underlying exposure, and then continue to pursue additional gains through upside-biased short-term derivatives trading whenever the opportunity presents itself through the winter of 25/26.

The only weakness of the natural gas bull thesis is that the bullish consensus is held by a majority of industry veterans, which is understandably uncomfortable when it seems so obvious.

But so far, the natural gas market has worked very well.

*I took advantage of the decline in early April to buy a lot of $AR common stock, and as I already mentioned, I'm doing some short-term buy trades on NG futures.

China’s Coal Calculus: Security vs. Sovereignt

1. Geopolitical Fuel Triggers

   - Taiwan and LNG Fears: China coal for several reasons:
     - 45% of its LNG (liquefied natural gas) imports pass through the Malacca Strait, which is patrolled by the U.S.
     - Coal is domestically abundant, with reserves totaling 137 billion tons.
   
   - Nuclear Limitations: Nuclear power contributes only 5% of China’s energy. It is too slow and expensive to significantly replace coal on a large scale before 2035.

2. The Storage Gap

   - China requires over 1,000 GWh of storage capacity for renewables to effectively replace coal, but currently, it has less than 50 GWh.
   - As a result, coal "peakers" are used to back up renewables during periods of low generation, which comes at a substantial cost—approximately 1.4 billion tons of CO₂ emissions per year.

3. Renewable Contradiction

   - China is a leader in renewable energy, adding 230 GW in 2023:
     - However, the grid cannot integrate all this renewable energy without coal balancing, which saw an additional 48 GW of coal capacity added in 2023.
   
   - Thus, coal is not replacing renewables; rather, it is facilitating their growth during a challenging transition.
   - For China, coal acts as a "transition" resource, providing vital energy sovereignty amid the looming threats of U.S. sanctions and the ongoing Taiwan conflict.

Nigeria's Cocoa Just Did What Oil Couldn't

Nigeria’s cocoa exports skyrocketed from N171 billion in 2023 to N2.71 trillion in 2024, a 1,486% jump, fueled by improved processing, mechanized farming, and value-added products.

This surge has revitalized agriculture, boosting forex earnings and creating jobs.

Stock Market Impact

FTN Cocoa Processors Plc, a major player, saw its stock climb from a 200-day average of N1.87 to N2.40, nearing its 52-week high of N2.75, with 1.72 million units traded at N4.18 billion.

Investors are increasingly drawn to agribusiness due to its strong growth potential.

Drivers of the Surge

Government Support: Export Expansion Grants and agro-processing loans enhance competitiveness.

Global Demand: High demand for quality cocoa products in Europe and Asia.

Investor Shift: Portfolios are pivoting to agriculture as a high-potential sector.

Naira Devaluation: Boosts profitability of cocoa exports, serving as a currency hedge.

Enhanced Processing: Upgraded facilities improve efficiency and minimize waste.

Outlook and Challenges

Nigeria could rise to a top global cocoa exporter, driving investment in agro-processing and logistics.

Challenges like infrastructure gaps and climate risks persist, but the sector’s outlook is robust.

‼️EU targets Russian energy and banks in toughest sanctions yet

The EU is introducing a sweeping new package of sanctions against Russia, aimed at crippling its energy exports, financial system, and military supply chains.

🔹 Key measures include:
– Cutting the oil price cap from $60 to $45 per barrel
– Banning the use of Nord Stream pipelines
– Disconnecting 22 more Russian banks from SWIFT
– Expanding the oil import ban to cover third-country refined products
– Sanctioning 77 ships from Russia’s “shadow fleet”
– Blocking exports worth €2.5B in dual-use tech and industrial goods
– Targeting Russia’s sovereign wealth fund (RDIF)

Ursula von der Leyen: “This war must end. Russia’s economy is under pressure — and we’re tightening the grip.”

The EU hopes to finalize the package before the G7 summit in Canada this week, where Ukraine will participate.

After the US refused to extend the oil licenses to American oil companies like @Chevron in Venezuela, the CCP has moved in, and Venezuela's oil exports held steady in May 2025, thanks to a surge in shipments to China, offsetting a drop in U.S.-authorized sales. 

The U.S. Treasury and State Department revoked licenses for @PDVSA partners in March, giving firms until May 27th of this year to wind down their transactions. This led to reduced deliveries to traditional U.S. and European markets, with PDVSA canceling some cargoes to Chevron amid payment uncertainties thanks to US Sanctions on Venezuela

However, China stepped in, just as I said they would if the licenses were not extended, and China is now importing 584,000 barrels per day (bpd) as of May, up from 521,000 bpd in April, becoming Venezuela's top oil destination. 

This shift highlights China's growing role in supporting Venezuela's oil industry amid tightened U.S. sanctions, and its total proof that the CCP is expanding their economic control over Latin America as China aggressively continues their Belt and Road Initiative.

🚨 Here's a list of some of the lawsuits Tesla has filed against former employees for stealing trade secrets:

-Tesla v. Zhongjie “Jay” Li (2025)
Details: Tesla sued former Optimus program engineer Zhongjie “Jay” Li, accusing him of stealing confidential information related to humanoid robot technology, specifically advanced robotic hand sensors. Li worked at Tesla from August 2022 to September 2024 and allegedly downloaded sensitive files before leaving to found a rival startup, Proception Inc. The lawsuit was filed in federal court.
Status: Ongoing as of June 2025.

Tesla v. Alexander Yatskov (2022, Settled 2023)
Details: Tesla filed a lawsuit against former engineer Alexander Yatskov in May 2022, alleging he stole trade secrets related to its AI-training supercomputer, Dojo, by downloading confidential and proprietary information. The case was settled in April 2023, as reported in a San Francisco federal court filing.
Status: Settled.

Tesla v. Guangzhi Cao (2019–2021)
Details: Tesla sued former employee Guangzhi Cao, accusing him of stealing trade secrets related to Autopilot technology and sharing them with his new employer, XMotors (XPeng). The lawsuit claimed Cao downloaded proprietary information before leaving Tesla. The case highlighted risks of handling confidential materials in the digital age.
Status: Resolved (specific outcome not detailed in sources).

Tesla v. Unnamed Former Employees (2022, Sealed Case)
Details: Tesla is rumored to be the “victim company” in a sealed trade secret misappropriation lawsuit filed against two former employees. Limited details are available due to the sealed nature of the case, and the rumor status makes this less certain.
Status: Unknown (sealed case).

Tesla v. Former Employees and Zoox (Date Not Specified)
Details: Tesla filed lawsuits against former employees who joined Zoox, alleging they stole trade secrets and used them at their new employer. Specific names and dates are not provided in the source, but the case involved claims of misappropriation of proprietary information.

Tesla v. Former Employees for Nondisclosure Agreement Breaches (2023)
Details: In August 2023, Tesla sued unnamed former employees, claiming they violated nondisclosure agreements (NDAs) by sharing trade secrets. The lawsuit alleged the employees did not adhere to NDA terms, potentially disclosing proprietary information.

Tesla v. Unnamed Former Employee for NDA Breach (Date Not Specified)
Details: Tesla accused an unnamed former employee of breaking a nondisclosure agreement, with allegations of intellectual property theft. The source does not provide specific details on the employee or the nature of the stolen secrets.

More people unsubscribed from our free newsletter than any other day following Wednesday's email.

I sent out a newsletter outlining how we use relative strength to get into winning trades before everyone else.

I used our trade on $CVX from late 2021 as a focal point: 

We bought the strongest sector, in stocks that were showing relative strength, in a market that was beginning to breakdown.

It just so happened that Russia invaded Ukraine in February and our energy stocks shot up in value.

We had no idea that was going to happen. And that was the point.

Someone else did. There was a reason why the market wasn't selling energy stocks. And we caught onto that and followed along and made a bunch of money.

Fast forward to last Friday: 

The same situation. Energy stocks were, out of no where, showing relative strength.

Crude oil was back up and over a key level that made us act and so we did.

We bought $XOM -- and today they're up big.

The news headlines get the praise, but the profits came from a position being opened last Friday. 1 week ago. With no prior knowledge of war.

It was relative strength; the second most important idea in our Profits Over Prophets Framework.

I got replies back from Wedneday night's email along the lines of: 

"How dare you make light of Ukraines situation" or "This is sick. Who cares about your profits?"

I have bad news, folks. 

If you're in the market as a speculator, you have two choices:

- Act on what the market is telling you to make as much money as you possibly can,
- Get mad at everyone else who does it instead.

I'd rather be the winner. It's that simple.

Relative strength matters. And it can make you a lot of money if you're willing to listen.

Anyway, we're long a few energy stocks. We'll see how this summer plays out.

Iran just hinted at closing the Strait of Hormuz-a vital oil artery where 20% of the world’s seaborne crude flows.
Western media screams: Global crisis! Oil shock!
But let’s be clear:
China won’t be the one panicking.

1/
🇮🇷 Iran exports over 1 million barrels per day-mostly to one country: China.
Despite U.S. sanctions, China has remained Iran’s largest and most stable buyer, using gray shipping routes, RMB payments, and discreet refiners.

You think Iran wants to cut off its only lifeline?

2/
A Hormuz blockade would hit Japan, South Korea, India, and Europe far harder than China.
These U.S. allies get 70–90% of their oil from the Gulf.
Their tankers are more vulnerable.
Their dependency is greater.
Their panic is louder.

3/
🇨🇳 China isn’t invincible, but it is prepared:
• Strategic oil reserves = 90+ days
• Russian crude via land and sea
• Pipeline diversification via Central Asia and CPEC
• Quiet maritime routes via Oman and Pakistan
• Domestic production and demand management

4/
Let’s not forget:
A Hormuz crisis would skyrocket oil prices.
Guess who benefits?
• 🇷🇺 Russia: higher margins, tighter markets
• 🇮🇷 Iran: black-market premiums
• 🇨🇳 China: already stockpiled, buys cheap when others sell in panic

Only the West bleeds.

5/
So when Tehran rattles the Hormuz card, it’s not aimed at Beijing.
It’s a warning to Washington, London, and Tokyo:
“Block our economy, and we’ll block your oil.”

China?
China is watching-calmly, strategically, and with options in hand.

6/
The irony?
The West pushed Iran into China’s arms.
And now, the West is terrified of what China might do next.

Who’s afraid of Hormuz?
Not the dragon.

END
The Strait of Hormuz isn’t just a waterway.
It’s Iran’s geopolitical dead man’s switch.

If Tehran flips it:
• 🚫 20 million barrels of oil vanish from the global market
• 💥 Gas prices explode
• 📈 Insurance premiums skyrocket
• ❄️ LNG shipments from Qatar freeze

Iran doesn’t need nukes to shake the world.
It already controls the valve.

I keep seeing people explaining to me that it doesn't matter if Israel's strikes disrupt Iranian oil exports since only China buys oil from Iran. This is deeply confused, but that confusion seems very widespread, so it's worth explaining why.

The oil market is global, so if you reduce Iranian exports, it will increase prices for everyone and not just China because the Chinese will have to get the oil they're no longer getting from Iran from somewhere else and that will bid prices up.

Of course, that's not the only or even the main reason why the war increases oil prices, the main reason is that, because of the risk of regional spillover, as long as it lasts it creates uncertainty about the reliability of oil supplies and that's reflected in prices.

What are alternatives if Iran closes the straits of Harmouz, Grok?

If Iran were to close the Strait of Hormuz, a critical chokepoint for roughly 20-30% of global oil trade, the primary alternative for oil and gas exports from the Persian Gulf would be limited-capacity pipelines bypassing the strait. Here’s an overview of the main alternatives and their challenges:
1. Existing Pipelines
Saudi Arabia’s Petroline (East-West Pipeline):
Capacity: Approximately 5 million barrels per day (bpd).
Route: Connects oil fields in eastern Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea port of Yanbu, bypassing the Strait of Hormuz.
Status: Has spare capacity of about 2 million bpd, but this is insufficient to cover the 17-20 million bpd typically transiting the strait.📷
Challenges: Limited spare capacity, vulnerability to regional instability (e.g., Houthi attacks in the Red Sea), and the need for upgrades to handle significantly increased volumes.
Abu Dhabi’s Crude Oil Pipeline:
Capacity: Around 1.5 million bpd.
Route: Transports oil from Abu Dhabi’s oil fields to the port of Fujairah on the Gulf of Oman, bypassing the strait.
Status: Can handle roughly 75% of the UAE’s crude output, but this is a fraction of the region’s total exports.📷
Challenges: Limited capacity and inability to compensate for other Gulf producers like Iraq or Kuwait.

Iraq’s Pipelines:
Capacity: The Iraq-Turkey Pipeline (partially operational) and southern export terminals like Basra have limited bypass potential.
Challenges: Many pipelines are outdated, under repair, or disrupted by geopolitical issues. Iraq relies heavily on the strait for exports.📷

Iran’s Jask Terminal:
Capacity: Limited, designed to handle some of Iran’s own exports.
Route: Located in the Gulf of Oman, bypassing the strait.
Status: Operational since 2021 but primarily serves Iran’s needs, not other Gulf producers.📷
Challenges: Iran’s own exports would be curtailed by a strait closure, and it’s unlikely to share capacity with rivals.

2. Unused or Underutilized Pipelines

Spare Capacity: The U.S. Energy Information Administration estimates about 2.6 million bpd of unused pipeline capacity from Saudi Arabia and the UAE combined.📷
Challenges: This is far below the volume needed to replace strait exports. Many pipelines are old, require maintenance, or face political and security risks (e.g., in Yemen or Syria).

3. Non-Pipeline Alternatives

Overland Transport: Trucking oil or gas is impractical due to the massive volumes involved, high costs, and logistical complexities across conflict-prone regions.

Alternative Sea Routes: There are no viable maritime routes to bypass the Strait of Hormuz, as it’s the only sea passage from the Persian Gulf to the open ocean.📷

Increased Production Elsewhere: Countries like the U.S., Russia, or Canada could ramp up production, but this would take months and wouldn’t fully offset the immediate loss of Gulf oil. The U.S., now a major exporter, could mitigate some impact for Western markets.📷
Strategic Reserves: Nations like the U.S., China, and members of the International Energy Agency could release strategic petroleum reserves to stabilize markets temporarily, but this is a short-term fix.

4. Economic and Geopolitical Considerations

Impact on Global Markets: A closure would likely spike oil prices by 50% or more, potentially pushing prices above $100 per barrel, causing economic disruption worldwide.📷📷
Iran’s Own Losses: Closing the strait would cut Iran’s oil exports (1.65 million bpd in 2024), which account for 65% of its government revenue, risking domestic instability.📷📷

Military Response: The U.S. Fifth Fleet, based in Bahrain, and allied navies could reopen the strait through minesweeping, escorts, or airstrikes, though this risks escalation.📷📷

China and India: As major importers of Gulf oil, they would pressure Iran to avoid closure, as it would harm their economies more than Western nations.📷📷

5. Practicality of Closure

Iran has the capability to disrupt the strait using mines, anti-ship missiles, drones, or fast boats, but a sustained closure is unlikely due to international backlash and self-inflicted economic damage.📷📷
Historical precedent (e.g., the 1980s Tanker War) shows Iran has disrupted shipping but never fully closed the strait.📷

Conclusion

The primary alternatives—Saudi and UAE pipelines—offer limited capacity, covering only a fraction of the 17-20 million bpd transiting the strait. Global oil markets would face severe disruption, with no immediate substitute for Gulf exports. Mitigation would rely on strategic reserves, increased non-Gulf production, and military efforts to reopen the strait, but these are short-term or high-risk options. Iran’s own economic dependence on the strait makes a prolonged closure improbable.
📷

🇪🇺🚫 The European Commission will propose that the EU bans all new Russian gas contracts based on trade law, in a move that seeks to circumvent any potential veto from Hungary and Slovakia, - FT

Companies would be banned from signing any new contracts for Russian gas, effective immediately.

Existing short-term contracts, pipeline gas and LNG imports from Russia would have to be terminated from 2026, while those linked to long-term contracts would come to an end on January 1 2028, the summary said.

In a concession to Hungary and Slovakia, who import Russian gas, they will be granted an exemption until 2027 to phase out their existing gas contracts, two officials with knowledge of the proposal said.

‼️‼️‼️According to The New York Times, if the U.S. joins the strikes on Iran, Tehran is expected to begin mining the critically important Strait of Hormuz.

It appears that Iran plans to block the strait in this way, through which 20% of the world's oil trade passes — including oil from the UAE, Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait, and Iraq, which all rely on the Strait of Hormuz for market access.

At least in the short term, this would significantly increase fuel prices, which would benefit the Russian economy.

Stabilization of prices could occur if Saudi Arabia or another major oil producer sharply increases output, or if the conflict in Iran ends quickly enough for the crisis in the strait to be brief, allowing tanker traffic to resume without long-term disruption.

On 10 June, Zimbabwe announced that it would ban exports of lithium concentrates starting in 2027 to retain more profits from its rich mineral deposits through at least two firms with $1 billion in Chinese investment willing to turn raw lithium into battery-grade lithium for electric vehicles and portable devices. 

This move follows a 2022 ban on exports of lithium ore (the raw mined material), part of a broader crusade to benefit Zimbabwe’s economy and a trend amongst mineral-rich African states aiming to move beyond raw material exports. 

For example, Namibia halted exports of unprocessed lithium and rare earths in 2023 to drive domestic processing. In 2021, the Democratic Republic of the Congo tightened controls on cobalt and copper concentrates to encourage in-country refining. However, probably the most famous examples include those of the Alliance of Sahel States, comprising Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger. These three countries ousted Western-aligned leaders in recent years and have embarked on a decolonisation process that includes reclaiming natural resources from foreign hands.

Returning to Zimbabwe, the country boasts Africa's largest lithium reserves and is among the world's top lithium producers. 

Back in 2023, Zimbabwean Mines Minister Winston Chitando said that Zimbabwe needed to ‘move up the value chain.’ The government had required producers to submit plans by March 2024 for local processing.

🦔 China's rare earth magnet exports crashed in May, showing how trade disputes can disrupt critical supply chains.
China controls 90% of global rare earth magnet production. These materials are essential for electric vehicles, wind turbines, and electronics.

May impact:
• U.S. imports fell 92% vs last year
• Global exports dropped 76%
• U.S. got just 46 tons vs 400+ tons in March
• Vietnam and Germany saw smaller declines

China imposed export controls in April during trade tensions but was selective about which countries got cut off. The U.S. bore the brunt while other nations continued receiving supplies.

Trump claims the issue was "resolved" after June meetings, but May's data shows significant damage to U.S. manufacturers who depend on these materials.

This episode highlights why companies are now prioritizing supply chain diversification. When one country controls 90% of a critical material, trade disputes can quickly shut down production lines.

It's a clear example of how trade policy directly impacts real manufacturing and forces businesses to rethink their sourcing strategies.

⭕ Unlike in the past, Sri Lanka’s grid today has less need for intermittent sources like rooftop solar. Without integrated storage, solar creates imbalances and burdens the grid. The government should shift focus and promote battery-backed solar systems, which support grid stability and reduce reliance on fossil fuels during peak hours.

Who has the most to lose if the Strait of Hormuz is shut down?

Not the US. It’s China.

China relies heavily on oil flowing through that chokepoint. Nearly 45 percent of its total oil imports, about 5.4 million barrels per day, come through the Strait of Hormuz. A closure would cut off almost half of its crude supply and trigger a major energy crisis in China. Not clear Iran can actually pull it off.

#US calls on #China to prevent #Iran from closing Strait of Hormuz and disrupting global oil flows

U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Sunday called for China to prevent Iran from closing the Strait of Hormuz, one of the most important trade routes for crude oil in the world.

"I encourage the Chinese government in Beijing to call them about that, because they heavily depend on the Straits of Hormuz for their oil," Rubio said in an interview on Fox News. China is Iran's most important oil customer and maintains friendly relations with the Islamic Republic.

Iran's foreign minister warned earlier Sunday that the Islamic Republic "reserves all options to defend its sovereignty," after the U.S. bombed three key nuclear sites over the weekend.

Iranian state-owned media, meanwhile, reported that Iran's parliament backed closing the Strait of Hormuz, citing a senior lawmaker. However, the final decision to close the strait lies with Iran's national security council, according to the report.

An attempt to block the narrow waterway between Iran and Oman could have profound consequences for the global economy. Some 20 million barrels per day of crude oil, or 20% of global consumption, flowed through the strait in 2024, according to the Energy Information Administration.

Oil prices could shoot above $100 per barrel if the strait is closed for a prolonged period, according to Goldman Sachs and consulting firm Rapidan Energy. JPMorgan analysts view the risk of Iran closing Hormuz as low because the U.S. would view such a move as a declaration of war.

Rubio said it would be "economic suicide" for Iran to close the strait because the Islamic Republic's oil also passes through the waterway. Iran is the third-largest oil producer in OPEC, pumping 3.3 million barrels per day. It exports at least 1.6 million bpd, with nearly 80% sold to China, according to the EIA.

Closure of the Strait of Hormuz & the impact on the price of farm produce in Nigeria.

Surge in Oil and Fuel Prices: The Strait of Hormuz handles about 20% of global oil and 20% of LNG trade. A closure could push Brent crude oil prices to $120-$150 per barrel, or even $350 in extreme scenarios. Nigeria, despite being an oil producer, relies heavily on imported refined petroleum products due to limited domestic refining capacity. A spike in global oil prices would increase the cost of petrol and diesel, potentially reaching N2,000-N3,000 per litre in Nigeria.

Increased Agricultural Input Costs: Nigerian farmers depend on imported inputs like fertilizers, pesticides, and machinery fuel. The Middle East, via the Strait, supplies 16.3% of global seaborne fertilizer trade. A closure would disrupt these supplies, driving up prices.

Food Inflation and Supply Chain Disruptions: Higher fuel and input costs would translate to elevated food prices. Nigeria’s inflation rate, already high (around 32% in mid-2025), could worsen as transport and production costs due to our Nigeria’s import-dependent economy. Additionally, Nigeria imports agricultural commodities like wheat and sugar through global trade routes affected by higher shipping costs and insurance premiums, exacerbating food price hikes.

Currency Pressure and Economic Instability: Nigeria’s reliance on oil exports (over 80% of foreign exchange earnings) means a global price spike could temporarily boost revenue, but a Strait closure would disrupt trade logistics, weakening the naira due to higher import bills. A weaker naira would make imported inputs and food even more expensive, hitting consumers hard. Rural farmers, often operating on thin margins, would struggle to absorb these costs, potentially reducing output and tightening food supply.

Mitigating Factors: Nigeria has strategic petroleum reserves covering 9-10 days of consumption, which could buffer short-term disruptions. Diversified oil imports from Russia, the U.S., and West Africa (e.g., Nigeria’s 5% crude imports from Africa) could ease some pressure. However, these measures are insufficient for a prolonged closure, and global spare oil capacity (5.7 million bpd, mostly in Saudi Arabia and UAE) is largely Strait-dependent, limiting relief.

Estimated Impact: Based on historical precedents like the 1970s oil shocks, a sustained closure could double or triple transport and input costs, potentially increasing staple food prices (e.g., rice, yam, or tomatoes) by 30-50% within weeks. Poorer households, spending 60-70% of income on food, would face severe hardship

JPMorgan Warns Tariffs Could Slow Growth, Fuel Inflation

In a mid-year report, JPMorgan analysts warned that U.S. tariffs may weaken global growth and reignite inflation, raising the chance of a 2024 recession to 40%. The bank cut its 2025 U.S. GDP forecast to 1.3% (from 2%), citing tariffs' "stagflationary impact."

While bearish on the dollar—expecting slower U.S. growth and stronger EM currencies—the bank predicts the Fed will cut rates by 100bps from December 2025 to spring 2026, with deeper cuts if the economy falters. It remains bullish on U.S. stocks, citing consumer and economic resilience.

For years, China has been buying discounted Iranian oil in bulk, and the U.S. sanctions on Tehran have barely put a dent in that trade, thanks to a shadow supply chain of transshipment and a yuan-denominated payment system that bypasses the U.S. dollar.

Chinese customs have not shown any oil shipped from Iran since July 2022. Ship tracking data from analytics firm Kpler, however, indicated China’s Iranian crude imports have continued to rise since then, nearly doubling to 17.8 million barrels per day (mbd) in 2024 from the 2022 level.

In the first five months of this year, those imports have remained at an elevated level of 6.8 mbd, little changed from the same period in 2024.

China is still the largest consumer of Iranian crude by far. The U.S. Energy Information Administration suggested in a report in May that nearly 90% of Iran’s crude oil and condensate exports continued to flow to China.

Another problem with the CA Budget.  They are now paying for Fire Suppression (about $1 Billion) out of taxes that CA companies pay for climate change (also called Cap & Trade).  We ultimately pay these taxes because they are passed on in higher gas prices, utilities and goods. 

It makes sense to pay for Fire Prevention out of this fund (removing brush, trees, dangerous fuels so that we don’t have catastrophic fires with huge emissions).  But they are only using $200 million to do that important work. 

Paying for Fire Supression (firefighter response) makes no sense because that is responding to catastrophic fires that have already started, not preventing them.  This has usually been a General Fund cost but that is now being moved over to Cap & Trade to balance the budget.  

It’s even more problematic because when they want to use that money for some new “green” project like High Speed Rail, the firefighter budget will get cut. 

In sum this is very bad budget planning that leaves us short on wildfire prevention and vulnerable on funding our state firefighters.

This factory is a big deal — most people didn’t even know Tesla was building its own LFP battery cell plant in the U.S.

Right now, Tesla imports all LFP batteries for its Megapack product from China. Building them locally will reduce geopolitical risk and potentially lower costs, as some Tesla patents suggest its own LFP designs could be cheaper than even Chinese-sourced ones.

Tesla also stopped selling lower-cost, standard range vehicles with LFP batteries in the U.S. because the batteries didn’t meet EV credit sourcing requirements. Now they’ll be able to claim the 45x manufacturing credit for the battery modules and the inverters, directly reducing costs. TBD on when/if that manufacturing credit will disappear though with Trump's bill. Regardless, U.S. made is good.

Crude Oil Import from US 🤔

India has increased its crude oil imports from the United States following Donald Trump’s inauguration as the 47th President on January 20, 2025. 

After a February 2025 meeting between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Trump, India committed to boosting energy purchases from the U.S., with Foreign Secretary Vikram Misri indicating that imports could rise from $15 billion to $25 billion in the near future. Data shows U.S. crude oil exports to India increased to 357,000 barrels per day in February 2025, up from 221,000 barrels per day the previous year, and further rose by 67% to 244,000 barrels per day in March 2025. This aligns with Trump’s push to maximize U.S. oil and gas exports and reduce the U.S. trade deficit with India.

Iraq’s lack of a national oil and gas law has caused:
⛔️Tensions between Baghdad and Erbil over oil exports and revenue sharing.
⛔️Legal uncertainty for international oil companies (IOCs).
⛔️Disputes in international courts (e.g., Turkey pipeline case, arbitration rulings).
🟢 Current status:
Iraq still operates without a national oil and gas law.
Oil sector is governed by:
☑️Iraqi Constitution (2005)
☑️MOUs and contracts by the Ministry of Oil
☑️Regional laws (such as KRG 2007 law)
☑️Customary practices and political agreements

2⃣ Other countries in the region have officially supported Iran during various crises, and closing the strait could push them into Israel’s camp. 
 
3⃣ Iran shares control over the strait with Oman.
 
4⃣ Closing the strait would antagonize China.

📢Iraq ranked first among the 12 OPEC producers in terms of exports to the United States. 🛢️🤑
Iraq has boosted exports in recent years, including to the United States, as it hasn’t adhered to its supply quota under the OPEC+ agreements.
But in May, Iraq cut its crude oil production by 50,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 3.93 million bpd, compared to its target of 4.049 million bpd, according to the latest OPEC data from secondary sources.

Iraq is compensating for previous overproduction as it has been one of the main overproducers in the OPEC+ deal for years, alongside Kazakhstan and Russia, non-OPEC members of the OPEC+ pact. 

Iraq ranked first among the 12 OPEC producers in terms of exports to the United States in May. Shipments totaled nearly 7 million barrels of crude, 6.95 million barrels to be precise.

The second-largest OPEC supplier to the U.S. was Nigeria with 6.803 million barrels of crude oil exports, followed by Saudi Arabia with 6.208 million barrels of crude.

Last month, estimates put Iraq’s crude oil exports to the United States surging past 5 million barrels in May, marking Baghdad’s highest monthly volume to U.S. refiners so far this year.

The surge reflects sustained U.S. appetite for heavier Middle Eastern grades, with Iraqi crude averaging between 160,000 bpd and 190,000 bpd in May.

As OPEC+ maintains voluntary output curbs and U.S. shale growth moderates, Iraq has solidified its position among Washington’s top five crude suppliers.

Iraq’s export increase also provides critical fiscal relief for Baghdad, with crude sales accounting for roughly 90% of Iraq’s state revenue.

Recent price support near $80 per barrel has further underpinned Iraq’s monthly revenues, helping finance public sector wages and infrastructure projects.

Known as the "Country of White Gold," Uzbekistan, located at the central Asia, has rich resources of gold, cotton, petroleum, and natural gas. China and Uzbekistan share a long history of trade dating back at least 2,000 years to the Ancient Silk Road. With the development of the China-Europe Railway Express, this vital economic lifeline has transported green beans, raisins, and other agricultural products to dining tables across China. Launched in 2024, the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan railway has further deepened connectivity across Eurasia and is expected to be completed in the coming years.

In recent years, Uzbekistan has identified tourism as a key strategic industry, implementing a series of 'rapid reforms" aimed at the fundamental transformation of the entire sector. Due to Uzbekistan's visa-free policy to China since 2020, increasing numbers of Chinese tourists are visiting the country, drawn to its more than 7,300 cultural heritage sites.

In January, 2025, Uzbekistan joined BRICS as a partner country. #BRICS2025 #MyBRICSStory #BRICSStory

US: Sanctions imposed on networks facilitating trade in Iranian oil

⚪️The US Treasury Department announced in a statement that it had imposed sanctions on “networks that transported and purchased billions of dollars’ worth of Iranian oil.”

⚪️According to the Treasury Department’s explanations, this is the eighth round of sanctions imposed by the Trump administration since signing the executive order implementing the maximum pressure strategy against Iran.

⚪️Along with the Treasury Department’s actions, the US State Department also imposed sanctions on 6 companies and 4 vessels, accusing them of participating in the trade in Iranian oil and petroleum products.

⚪️The US Treasury Department also included 1 individual, 21 companies, and 11 vessels in the sanctions list.

FACT: Israel and Iran maintained significant covert trade in oil and weapons until the late 1980s, with activity declining but not disappearing entirely into the 1990s.
Oil Trade:
•From the mid-1950s until the 1979 Iranian Revolution, Iran was Israel’s primary oil supplier, providing over 90% of Israel’s oil imports at times. This relationship was highly secretive, with both sides concealing the extent of their cooperation due to regional sensitivities and Arab opposition.
•After the 1979 Revolution, official diplomatic relations ceased, but clandestine oil trade continued into the 1980s. Iranian oil was sold to Israel through covert channels and intermediaries, such as the Swiss trader Marc Rich, and transported via a secret pipeline.
•This covert oil trade persisted throughout the Iran–Iraq War (1980–1988), with Israeli arms sales to Iran often being paid for in oil shipments. The arrangement reportedly continued sporadically and unofficially even after the war, though at a reduced scale.
Weapons Trade:
•During the Iran–Iraq War, Israel was a major supplier of arms to Iran, selling an estimated $500 million to $2 billion worth of weapons annually in the early 1980s. These included anti-tank guns, missiles, spare parts for aircraft, and other military equipment.
•Much of this arms trade was facilitated with the tacit approval of the United States, particularly as part of efforts to prevent an Iraqi victory and later as part of the Iran–Contra Affair (1985–1986).
•Arms sales continued after the Iran–Iraq War, but became more sporadic and unofficial, with some reports of Israeli arms deals with Iran into the early 1990s

Symphony: A World Where I Don’t Have to Trade Anymore

If you’ve ever spent your day thinking:

“Should I do this on Ethereum or Solana…?”
“Why is gas so high again?”
“Why am I still doing this manually…?”

Then let me introduce you to @symphonyio —the protocol that says: “Don’t trade harder. Trade smarter. Actually, don’t trade at all. Let your agents do it.”

Symphony is not just another protocol.
It’s an Agentic Financial Layer—a new financial operating system where agents trade, think, and coordinate for you.

And these aren’t your average bots.
Symphony agents make decisions, execute strategies, manage risks—and most importantly, they do it together. Welcome to agent collaboration:

one agent handles strategy, another handles execution, another handles risk.
Basically, you now have a trading team that doesn’t sleep, panic, or check Twitter for price action.

Best part? These agents are chain-agnostic.
They don’t care which blockchain you’re on.
Ethereum? Solana? Arbitrum? Bitcoin L2?

To them, it’s all just one big playground.

And because they’re not limited by chain boundaries, they can execute across all of them.
That’s cross-chain execution in action.

Your trade might source liquidity on Solana, hedge on Arbitrum, and settle on Bitcoin L2—all automatically, all in sync.

It’s like giving your agents a passport and telling them,
“Go make me money—wherever it is.”

But what about scalability?

That’s where trade sharding comes in.
Instead of queuing all transactions through one chokepoint, Symphony shards them across chains, agents, and strategies.
More throughput. More speed. Less gas. More alpha.

The result?
Trades that are faster, smarter, and infinitely scalable.

Of course, someone needs to coordinate all this madness. That’s the job of the Orchestrator—Symphony’s real-time control tower.

It tells each agent what to do, when to act, and how to adapt to market conditions. It prevents conflicts, reroutes failing strategies, and keeps your whole agent team moving like a synchronized orchestra.
(And yes, it’s probably a better manager than your boss.)

So no, Symphony is not just another trading app.
It’s not a dashboard.
It’s not a bot.

It’s a living, breathing system:
- Built on a chain-agnostic foundation
- Capable of cross-chain execution
- Scaling with trade sharding
- Managed by a real-time orchestrator
- Powered by intelligent agent collaboration
→ All together forming the Agentic Financial Layer.

You no longer need to click buttons, sign transactions, or stress over bridges. Symphony thinks, plans, and acts for you.

So next time the market goes crazy…
Feel free to sip your coffee.

Symphony’s already on it.

A stronger New Development Bank

A SWIFT alternative
 - Shields against U.S. sanctions
 - Ends monopoly over cross-border transfers

Debt rebellion

The dollar’s age of impunity is ending.

The tropical Main Development Region of the Atlantic is currently warming significantly, and it can be easily seen as to why when looking 850mb wind charts over the last few days. Weaker than average trade winds and vorticity within the intertropical convergence zone in the low-latitudes have allowed for reduced upwelling, and the sea surface temperature anomaly (SSTA) configuration has improved as a result.

With trade winds expected to continue being weaker than average over the next couple of weeks, favorable changes in the background state of the basin are possible with a weaker differential between tropical and subtropical SSTAs being present.

Trump considering global oil embargo against Russia

U.S. President Donald Trump is seriously weighing the introduction of tough secondary sanctions against countries that continue to trade oil with Russia — including China, India, and Turkey. The plan involves supporting a bill that would impose a 500% tariff on imports from Russia, effectively amounting to a global oil embargo.

According to The Times, this shift in Trump’s stance is driven by his growing frustration with Vladimir Putin’s refusal to engage in peace talks and continued strikes on civilian targets in Ukraine. Trump had previously called the bill “too harsh,” but now says he is “studying it carefully.”

The outlet notes that the key concern is the risk of economic fallout. The White House wants to ensure that the power to lift sanctions remains with the president, while Congress is pushing for more oversight. Analysts believe that even partial implementation of the measures could significantly damage the Russian economy.

🚨 Rumors swirl that @POTUS may be preparing a massive move to end Putin’s war by tanking Russia’s oil revenues — maybe as soon as Monday.

Could he do it? He’s the one person on Earth who might actually pull it off.

🧵Here’s how:

1. The idea? Crush Russia’s oil exports, which fund ~40% of the Kremlin’s budget. But there’s a twist: He hates high oil prices more than any president in history. If he goes through with this, it’s a game of chicken — between oil prices and economic war.

2. For context: Russia exports ~7 million barrels/day of oil & petroleum products (of which about 4.5mbpd crude; of that India buys about 1.7mbpd and China about 2.2mbpd). 

That’s too much for even OPEC to replace if such sanctions deter Indian & Chinese refiners perfectly for a while. 

Of course, oil markets are never perfect. Instead, oil always finds a way. Sellers and buyers meet — sanctions or not. 

But that is ONLY true over time. In the short term, sanctions force all actors to reconsider their positions and thus absolutely create a supply shock to the market if introduced on a tight timeline.

3. Today, India and China buy some 70% of Russian crude, mostly at a discount. This isn’t a loophole — it’s by design. Western sanctions aim to limit Russia’s income while keeping prices manageable for the West. That is also why the West (US & Europe) introduced the sanctions gradually over 12-15 months in 2022. It gave everyone the time to rearrange themselves. 

But Trump’s approach may flip that script. He could introduce a tariff shock with immediate effect to which oil prices will react because — for the very least — the shorts are forced to cover their positions. 

4. The proposed Sanctioning Russia Act of 2025 targets countries helping fund Russia’s war by continuing to import Russian energy.

It proposes a 500% tariff (!!) on imports by the United States from countries (like India & China) that buy Russian oil.

5. That’s a big stick. And Trump could wield it effectively — if he’s willing to stomach the oil price shock that might follow for a limited period.

6. The bill also includes an escape hatch, giving Trump max leverage to negotiate peace with the Kremlin: The president can issue a 180-day waiver to any country based on U.S. national security interests. 

A second waiver may be possible under certain conditions (per Hill reporting). This gives flexibility — and leverage.

⸻

Bottom line: If Trump backs this fully, it could mark the most aggressive energy sanctions in modern history. Big oil, geopolitics, tariffs, and a high-stakes showdown with Putin and oil markets — all in one.

#Sudan’s war:  an economic shockwave shaking the entire region 

A new report by The East African @The_EastAfrican highlights the growing economic toll of the Sudan conflict on neighboring countries. The war has disrupted trade, transport, oil routes, and markets across East and Central Africa.

Here’s what’s happening:

1️⃣ Kenya: Sudanese trade through Mombasa is declining, affecting Kenyan exporters and transport corridors.

2️⃣ Uganda: Cross-border trucking and trade into Sudan have collapsed.

3️⃣ Ethiopia : Lost access to a key regional export market and suspended several land routes.

4️⃣ South Sudan: Crippled by the halt in oil exports via Sudanese pipelines.

5️⃣ Chad & Eritrea : Suffering from shrinking border markets and rising instability due to spillover from the war.

RECORD SOYBEAN EXPORTS IN FIRST HALF OF 2025

Argentina's soybean exports hit a historic high in the first half of 2025, with 31.1 million tons registered, comprising 61% subproducts, 24% beans, and 14% oil, according to the Rosario Stock Exchange.

This surge, driven by a temporary reduction in export taxes, also led to a record $16 billion in US dollars.

Viterra led soybean complex sales, excelling in oil and subproducts with 1.1 and 4.2 million tons, respectively, while ADM Agro topped bean exports with 1.1 million tons.

Overall, Cargill led grain exports with 9.6 million tons, followed by Viterra and Cofco, highlighting Argentina's robust agro-export sector.

Source: Argentine Central Bank and @SalvadorVitell1 
@JMilei

We couldn’t have fumbled something that was never properly structured to benefit us in the first place. AGOA wasn’t a bilateral trade agreement, it was a unilateral ‘gift’. From the onset, it was extractive. No surprise there; we don’t have much to export to the U.S. except oil and other raw materials.

Any trade deal that doesn’t include serious investment in infrastructure, production capacity, and technology transfer is not a good deal for Africa. You can’t export what you don’t produce. So no, Africa didn’t fumble AGOA, it simply wasn’t built for our industrial development. It was built to serve U.S. strategic interests.

And let’s not ignore the ridiculous conditions. One of them? That participating countries must never undermine U.S. national security. What does that even mean? It’s vague, political, and imperial. AGOA wasn’t just about trade, it was a soft-power tool to secure African allegiance and push back against rising competitors like China.

If the U.S. wants to be taken seriously as a partner, it needs to restructure AGOA to reflect real partnership, where African nations gain the tools to produce, compete, and grow sustainably. Until then, let’s stop pretending we fumbled anything.

‼️ On July 18, 2025, the EU agreed on the 18th sanctions package against Russia, which provides for further restrictions on energy trade.

The price of Russian oil is now strictly limited to $47.6 per barrel – approximately 15% below the average market price over the last three months. The sanctions package also includes a ban on transactions related to the Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines, meaning that Russia's plans to "rescue" this infrastructure through the US are now futile.

Russia's hopes of blocking the adoption of the new package with the help of Hungary and Slovakia also did not materialize. Slovakia received a guarantee of protection against gas supply disruptions until 2028 and supported the EU's joint decision.

Against this backdrop, India announced its readiness to replace Russian oil with Middle Eastern oil. On July 17, Indian Minister of Petroleum and Natural Gas Hardeep Singh Puri confirmed that Delhi was ready to switch from Russia to other sources (Brazil, Canada, Guyana, the Middle East). The number of countries supplying oil to India has increased from 27 to 40 over the past month, confirming India's readiness to adapt quickly.

‼️ How this will affect Russia's economy:

◾️ In the coming months, budget-generating oil and gas revenues should fall sharply (a reduction of at least 30–40% is forecast). Inflation will accelerate, and the ruble will weaken;
◾️ The room for circumventing sanctions is narrowing;
◾️ If India switches to alternative suppliers, this will deprive Russia of a market share that is extremely important to it;
◾️ The introduction of sanctions on Nord Stream operations "shuts down" potential loopholes and Moscow's "investment maneuvers" to return to the European market.

The Kremlin understands the severity of the economic consequences of continuing the war, but is not seeking a political solution. Russia understands that the US is also considering the possibility of imposing new sanctions, but there are currently no signs that Putin is ready for de-escalation and genuine peace talks.

Negotiations and the positions of the parties involved - the EU, the US, and China - are important factors that will determine how the situation develops and whether further sanctions will be imposed.

🚨IQD RV: SALARY RESOLUTION IN ERBIL BAGHDAD “SIGNAL”

WASHINGTON DC - The United States said on Saturday that the resolution of Erbil-Baghdad tensions over oil exports and finances would signal that the Iraqi government is committed to creating a suitable environment for companies to invest in the country. 

“We have consistently encouraged Baghdad and Erbil to resolve their issues regarding salaries and the reopening of the ITP,” a State Department official told Rudaw in response to an email, referring to the Iraq-Turkey Pipeline. 

“Addressing these issues quickly would signal that Iraq puts the interests of its people first and is committed to creating an environment in which companies will want to invest. Establishing that business-friendly environment requires respecting contract sanctity and providing necessary security guarantees,” added the official.

Iraq’s Council of Ministers on Thursday approved a new financial agreement with the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), paving the way for the resumption of salary payments to the Region’s public employees and the restart of Kurdish oil exports, which have been suspended for more than two years. 

The Iraqi government said the agreement stipulates that the KRG is obliged to export all of the oil produced from its fields - estimated at 230,000 barrels per day - through Iraq’s State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO). The KRG will retain 50,000 barrels per day for local consumption, covering production costs, while the federal Ministry of Oil may provide refined oil products equivalent to 15,000 barrels per day if needed. Erbil will also hand over non-oil revenues. In return, Baghdad will pay the Kurdish government’s share from the federal budget.

The KRG, which approved the deal with the federal government ahead of its announcement by Baghdad, has not confirmed its contents. Kurdish Prime Minister Masrour Barzani said he welcomed their “understanding” and expected Baghdad to resume the disbursement of the salaries of his government’s civil servants who have only been paid for four months this year. 

With the announcement of their agreement, drone attacks on locations in the Kurdistan Region have stopped. In the month of July, there were at least 18 drone attacks. Oil fields operated by international companies have been a primary target. The last incident occurred on Thursday when two explosive-laden drones crashed in the outskirts of Erbil, according to the Erbil-based Directorate General of Counter Terrorism (CTD). Another drone attack was repelled on the same day in the Shekhan district of Duhok province, home to oil fields operated by international companies, a security source told Rudaw at the time.  

The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) has blamed the attacks on Iraq’s Popular Mobilization Forces (PMF), a charge Baghdad has denied.

Aziz Ahmad, deputy chief of staff to Prime Minister Barzani, said in a statement on Wednesday that the Region has lost nearly 200,000 barrels of oil production due to the “spate of drone attacks by criminal militias on the Iraqi government payroll.”

The attacks have been widely condemned, including by the UN, US and UK. 

“Demonstrating a commitment to safeguarding and supporting international investment is especially important in the current environment where drone attacks have targeted U.S. and other international companies’ operations in the Iraqi Kurdistan Region without consequence,” the State Department official noted in the email to Rudaw.
