TXOGA's Quarterly Perspective for 2025 Q3 is now available! Read here: https://t.co/aetRNBoWwd

Global economic risks—from trade policy to fiscal deficits—have been slower to materialize than many expected, leaving markets in a “soft landing” holding pattern. Yet uncertainty persists, and the real test for the U.S. outlook is whether record-high equities can continue sustaining consumer spending as corporate costs rise.

Against this backdrop, TXOGA’s latest outlook highlights several key themes:

✅ Global oil demand keeps setting records through 2026, even as EIA projects supply growth will outpace demand. With U.S. inventories still low, the downside risk in official forecasts depends on assumptions that Saudi Arabia and Russia will flood the market—an outcome that remains far from certain.

✅ Natural gas demand also reaches new highs, with roughly 85% of incremental LNG capacity growth in 2025 coming from North America. Texas continues to lead U.S. production, supported by new LNG export projects along the Gulf Coast.

✅ Texas shale productivity remains resilient. Gains in the Permian and Eagle Ford basins, even with fewer rigs, underscore efficiency improvements that keep supply steady.

The common thread: Texas oil and natural gas remain steady in a turbulent global environment. That stability provides a foundation for reliability and growth, but it is not a guarantee. Continued investment, operational discipline, and readiness for sudden change will remain critical for the state and nation to sustain their competitive advantage.

Day 3 at #IATF2025 featured the UNIDO Thematic Forum: Greening the Value Chain, a panel session that asked how Africa can turn sustainability commitments into industrial growth.

The conversation made one point clear: Africa’s green transition will only succeed when renewable energy projects are designed as complete ecosystems - bringing together policy, finance, and industry.

Boukhalfa Yaïci (Director General, Green Energy Cluster Algeria – GEC’A), Shenhong Yao (Director, Division of Strategic Planning & South-South Cooperation, @UNIDO ), Helen Aigbe Brume (Director & Global Head, Project & Asset-Based Finance, @afreximbank ), and Pradeep Paulose (Programme Officer, SPP/SSC, @UNIDO  – Moderator) shared insights on how to make this possible. 

The message was consistent: investors need visibility of future pipelines, governments must provide policy stability, and industries must have clarity on where to build capacity.

Algeria’s 3.2 gigawatt renewable programme was highlighted as an example of this approach in action. By mandating local content, opening tenders to domestic firms, and financing through local banks, it is not only adding clean power but also creating industries in cables, transformers, steel, and engineering.

The forum closed on an optimistic note: with the right frameworks, Africa’s renewable energy story will be measured not just in megawatts installed but in industries built, jobs created, and futures secured.

EU energy chief demands permanent ban on Russian imports

Moscow has long warned that cutting its oil and gas will damage the bloc’s economy

The European Union must permanently cut off all Russian energy imports, Commissioner for Energy and Housing Dan Jorgensen has declared.

Most EU countries have halted direct imports of Russian crude and gas under sanctions over the Ukraine conflict. However, Brussels continues to push for a full phase-out of Russian energy by the end of 2027 under its RePowerEU Roadmap. The plan calls for ending spot gas contracts, suspending new deals, limiting uranium imports, and targeting the so-called Russian “shadow fleet” of oil tankers allegedly used to bypass sanctions.

Jorgensen, who has championed the plan for months, said the bloc must urgently agree on its framework and stick to it even after the Ukraine conflict ends.

“For us the objective is very, very clear. We want to stop the import as fast as possible,” he told reporters in Copenhagen on Friday. “And in the future, even when there is peace, we should still not import Russian energy… In my opinion, we will never again import as much as one molecule of Russian energy once this agreement is made.”

Jorgensen noted that the US has backed Brussels’ plans. President Donald Trump, frustrated with slow Ukraine peace talks, urged European allies on Thursday to halt Russian energy imports. The July trade deal between Washington and Brussels also included a pledge that the EU would replace Russian oil and gas with American LNG and nuclear fuel.

Hungary and Slovakia, both heavily dependent on Russian supplies, have been the strongest opponents of the phase-out, arguing it would undermine the bloc’s security and raise prices. On Friday, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto accused the EU of “hypocrisy,” saying many members still buy Russian crude through intermediaries even as they call for a phase-out. Jorgensen said he was in talks with Budapest and Bratislava but noted the plan can be approved without them, as it requires only a qualified majority.

Modi-Trump Rift Deepens
Tariffs, Russian Oil, SCO Summit Test India-US Ties

India-US ties are facing their most turbulent period in years, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Donald Trump attempt to balance personal rapport with sharp disagreements over trade and energy. Trump recently doubled tariffs on Indian goods to 50 percent, punishing New Delhi for continuing Russian oil purchases, even calling India a “laundromat for the Kremlin.” India, instead of retaliating, chose to strengthen its domestic market by reforming the Goods and Services Tax to boost household consumption. 

Meanwhile, at the SCO Summit in Tianjin, images of Modi walking with Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin fueled US anxieties over shifting global alliances. Trump publicly vented frustration, later softening his stance by emphasizing friendship with Modi. Modi responded diplomatically, stressing strategic partnership. With Jaishankar set to address the UNGA and Putin’s visit expected later this year, India continues its delicate balancing act between East and West. The stakes for global power dynamics have never been higher.
Credit : India Today Global.

🌐🇻🇪Claudio Resta: Venezuela is a stranger to the drug trade… but it sits on a mountain of oil and is the cornerstone of Latin American independence..

This is not a drug war, but a robbery and a colonial war

According to the former Director General of the UN Office in Vienna and Executive Director of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (merged into the UN Office on Drugs and Crime), with the rank of Under-Secretary-General, the world's leading expert on drugs, Pino Arlacchi:

"This is another attempt by the US to interfere in a country that - according to the UN - has eradicated cocaine, marijuana and others, as well as the cartels that controlled their trade.

The geopolitics of oil disguised as a war on drugs. During my tenure as head of UNOC, the UN agency for drugs and crime, I have been to Colombia, Bolivia, Peru and Brazil, but I have never visited Venezuela.

There was simply no need. The cooperation of the Venezuelan government’s record on combating the drug trade was among the best in Latin America.

The country was full of problems, but it was not involved in the production, trafficking, or even consumption of hard drugs.

These are verified facts that today, in Trump’s delusional narrative of “Venezuela as a narco-state,” clearly show that these are geopolitically motivated slanders.

The analyses from the World Drug Report 2025, published by the organization I had the honor of leading, tell the exact opposite story to that propagated by the Trump administration. They shatter the fiction of the Cartel de los Soles—an alleged supercartel as legendary as the Loch Ness Monster, but suitable for justifying sanctions, embargoes, and threats of military intervention against a country that—coincidentally—sits on some of the largest oil reserves on the planet.

The recently released UN report on 2025 is crystal clear and should shame those who have been behind the demonization of Venezuela. The document mentions Venezuela only in passing, stating that only a negligible part of Colombian drug production passes through its territory to the US and Europe.

According to the UN, Venezuela has consolidated its historical position as a country without growing coca, marijuana, etc. – and without the presence of international criminal cartels.

The document only confirms 30 previous annual reports that do not mention the Venezuelan drug trade at all, because it simply does not exist.

Only 5% of Colombian drugs transit through Venezuela. A full 2,370 tons – ten times more – are produced or traded by Colombia itself, and 1,400 tons pass through Guatemala.

The “Cartel de los Soles” is a figment of Trump’s imagination. It is not mentioned in UN documents, nor in European or other international agencies. Only the DEA in the US refers to it – and that on the basis of classified data that would certainly not be secret if they had a real basis and confirmation from elsewhere.

According to a European report, cocaine is the second most used drug in the EU. Its main sources are clearly defined: Colombia (production), Central America (distribution) and various routes through West Africa (transportation to Europe). Venezuela and Cuba do not figure in this scenario.

In a sense, Maduro is to South America what Gaddafi was to Africa. Let's just hope that the same dark scenario does not repeat itself...

This Bloomberg snapshot gives a live view of U.S. natural gas flows across production, demand, imports/exports, and LNG movements.

Key Takeaways:

Production: U.S. gas production is still very strong — hovering at record levels despite minor daily declines.

Demand: Power burn remains the dominant demand driver, especially with summer cooling load — but it will ease as shoulder season begins.

Imports/Exports:  LNG exports remain a critical balancing factor — Sabine (+0.8 Bcf), Cameron (+0.1 Bcf), Freeport (+0.06 Bcf) all pulling volumes offshore.

U.S. gas flows show a market still flush with supply (~107 Bcf/d), but LNG exports (+14.6 Bcf/d) and strong power burn (~38 Bcf/d) are keeping balances tighter. Canada imports sliding, Mexico exports firm, and LNG terminals remain the swing factor in whether we stay oversupplied or not. #natgas

🔥KRG Council of Ministers Discusses Non-Oil Revenues and Oil Exports- The meeting’s first agenda item focused on Non-Oil Revenues and the Resumption of Oil Exports💥

The Council emphasized the importance of classifying non-oil revenues and sharing them with the federal government in accordance with Federal Financial Management Law No.6

ERBIL (Kurdistan24) – Kurdistan Region Prime Minister Masrour Barzani and Deputy Prime Minister Qubad Talabani chaired a meeting of the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) Council of Ministers on Wednesday to address critical economic and financial issues.
The meeting’s first agenda item focused on non-oil revenues and the resumption of oil exports. 

The Council emphasized the importance of classifying non-oil revenues and sharing them with the federal government in accordance with Federal Financial Management Law No. 6. It called on Baghdad to adopt the KRG’s proposal as a framework for resolving disputes over revenue-sharing, stressing that the Region is asserting its legal entitlements.

The Ministry of Natural Resources was instructed to accelerate efforts to restart oil exports. Acting Minister of Natural Resources Kamal Mohammad Salih reported that the ministry is actively coordinating with the Iraqi Oil Ministry and international oil companies to reach a tripartite agreement for the swift resumption of exports.

🔥Kurdistan Region Oil Exports to Resume Soon- SOMO Chief “I am optimistic about the positive measures and discussions taking place. Everyone is working in this direction, and this is cause for optimism. All that remains is Implementation so we are optimistic that it will be achieved soon.” Ali Nasir Faiq, Director General of SOMA

ERBIL, Kurdistan Region - The head of Iraq’s State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO) said on Monday that they are “working to implement the agreed-upon terms” to resume the Kurdistan Region’s long-halted oil exports, with exports expected to restart “soon.” 

Oil companies operating in the Kurdistan Region are demanding a tripartite signed agreement that includes the federal oil ministry and the Kurdistan Region's natural resources ministry to guarantee the payment of their dues.

Faiq stressed that SOMO is ready and “working to implement the agreed-upon terms” to resume the oil exports, stressing that the budget law and its amendments are the “strongest” guarantee for the payment of the companies’ dues. 

Oil exports from the Kurdistan Region through the Iraq-Turkey pipeline have been suspended since March 2023, when a Paris-based arbitration court ruled in favor of Baghdad against Ankara, saying the latter had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing Erbil to begin exporting oil independently in 2014.

The suspension has incurred $28 billion in lost revenue so far, according to the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG). 

The following is the full transcript of the interview with Ali Nizar Faiq:

Rudaw: There was much talk about reaching an agreement between Baghdad and Erbil, but this was followed by reports indicating that no agreement had been reached. Where do we stand now regarding the export of the Kurdistan Region's oil through SOMO?

Ali Nizar Faiq: The question is important, and the issue is even more important. We are directly linked to the issue through the budget law and its amendments. The law stipulates the need to begin pumping the Kurdistan Region's oil in two directions: the first is exporting oil through the oil marketing company that we manage, and the other is domestic consumption. Discussions began based on this foundation to establish the appropriate mechanism for implementing this law and its amendments, including selecting an international consultant and determining its work methodology. Furthermore, the Ministry of Oil appointed Wood Mackenzie as a global consultant. Discussions were also held with the Kurdistan Region's Ministry of Natural Resources, which is responsible for its contracts with producing companies within the Region and the rights and obligations of these companies under the contracts signed with them.

These discussions resulted in SOMO completing all its contracts with the companies purchasing Kurdistan Region oil. We are optimistic that these quantities will arrive and flow into the tanks at the Turkish port of Ceyhan, after which loading will begin normally.

So, based on the agreement, is the buyer currently ready?

Yes. The companies purchasing Kurdistan Region oil are ready. It is Iraqi oil, flowing through Iraqi-Turkish pipelines in accordance with the existing agreement with the Turkish side.

European countries as sponsors of war.

In August 2025, the five largest EU importers of Russian fossil fuels paid Russia a combined EUR 979 mn for fossil fuels. 

Natural gas — unsanctioned by the EU — accounted for more than 61% of these imports, delivered mainly by pipeline or as liquefied natural gas (LNG). 

The remainder was largely crude oil, which continues to flow to Hungary and Slovakia through the southern branch of the Druzhba pipeline under an EU exemption.

Hungary was the EU’s largest importer, purchasing EUR 416 mn worth of Russian fossil fuels. This included EUR 176 mn of crude oil and EUR 240 mn of pipeline gas.

Slovakia ranked second, with imports totaling EUR 276 mn. Crude oil delivered via the Druzhba pipeline made up 74% of the total (EUR 204 mn), while pipeline gas accounted for EUR 72 mn. The derogation allowing Slovak refineries to process Russian crude into oil products and re-export them to Czechia expired on 5 June.

France was the third-largest buyer, importing EUR 157 mn of Russian fossil fuels, all in the form of LNG. However, not all of this gas is consumed domestically — a study shows that some LNG entering through the Dunkerque terminal is subsequently delivered to Germany.

The Netherlands was the fourth biggest importer, importing EUR 65 mn of Russian LNG, while Belgium, in fifth place, purchased EUR 64 mn, also entirely in LNG.

FT:  US to urge G7 to impose high tariffs on China, India over Russian oil purchases:

"The US will pressure G7 countries to hit India and China with sharply higher tariffs for buying Russian oil in an attempt to "force" Moscow into peace talks with Ukraine, according to four people briefed on the plans.  

In a video call on Friday, finance ministers from the Group of Seven leading economies will discuss a US proposal for a round of new measures as Donald Trump steps up efforts to broker a peace deal in Ukraine.  The US president this week urged the EU to impose up to 100 per cent tariffs on China and India but is now expanding the push to include G7 allies.  “Chinese and Indian purchases of Russian oil are funding Putin’s war machine and prolonging the senseless killing of the Ukrainian people,” said a US Treasury department spokesperson.  

“Earlier this week, we made it clear to our EU allies that if they are serious about ending the war in their own backyard, they need to join us and impose meaningful tariffs that will be rescinded the day the war ends,” they added.  “President Trump’s Peace and Prosperity Administration is ready, and our G7 partners need to step up with us.”   The spokesperson declined to state a figure for the planned tariffs but people familiar with the situation said the US had proposed levels of between 50 and 100 per cent.   

The US last month increased tariffs on Indian imports to 50 per cent over the country’s purchases of Russian oil. In April, Trump sharply increased tariffs on Chinese imports but scaled them back in May after a severe market backlash.  EU officials know that imposing such steep tariffs on two key trading partners would be difficult given the economic impact and likely retaliation from Beijing. The bloc is hoping to seal a trade deal with New Delhi within weeks as it seeks closer ties with a rising Asian power.  

But Brussels hopes to persuade the US that it can achieve similar pressure through other measures such as tougher sanctions on Russian energy producers and bringing forward a 2027 deadline for its member states to stop buying Russian’s oil and gas.   That, three European officials said, would require Trump to put pressure on Hungary and Slovakia, two countries led by pro-Russian leaders who continue to buy Russian oil via pipeline and have vetoed tougher EU sanctions in the past. 

 The EU is already debating whether to put sanctions on China for buying cheap Russian oil and gas.  Dan Jørgensen, EU energy commissioner, met US energy secretary Chris Wright on Thursday to discuss replacing Russian liquefied natural gas for American supplies.  

“We need, as fast as possible, to make sure that we get rid of the dependency that we still have . . . on Russian energy,” he said.   The EU still buys around a fifth of its gas from Russia, down from 45 per cent before the country’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.   Canada, which holds the G7 presidency and hosted the group’s last summit in Alberta in June, said it called the meeting “following discussions with the US”.   It said they would “discuss further measures to increase pressure on Russia and limit their war machinery”.  

“The G7 is resolved in its opposition to Russia’s illegal and unjustified war,” said John Fragos, spokesperson for Canada’s finance minister.   The talks would include proposals for “tariffs on nations that continue to fund Russia’s war machinery”, said a Canadian government official who spoke on condition of anonymity.   

Ottawa also faces a dilemma over such a move. In June prime minister Mark Carney launched an effort to rekindle relations with India after a two-year rift. Similar overtures have been made to Beijing, as Canada diversifies its economy away from the US.

China threatened to respond to NATO countries imposing tariffs due to Russian oil purchases.

Trade-economic and energy cooperation between China and countries around the world, including Russia, is legal, said Foreign Ministry representative Lin Jian.

China will take decisive countermeasures if NATO countries, under pressure from the US, attempt to impose tariffs on the People's Republic under the pretext of purchasing Russian oil. This was stated by the official representative of the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Lin Jian.

"Normal trade-economic and energy cooperation between China and countries worldwide, including Russia, is legal and raises no objections," he emphasized at a briefing, commenting on the possibility of G7 and NATO countries imposing tariffs on China for importing Russian oil. "In case of violation of China's legitimate rights and interests, it will decisively take countermeasures; we will firmly defend our sovereignty, security, and development interests."
As the Chinese diplomat clarified, the actions of the United States, trying to pressure the European Union, are "a typical example of unilateral intimidation and economic coercion." He noted that Washington thereby "seriously undermines international trade rules, threatens the security and stability of global production and supply chains."

"Facts have proven that coercion and pressure are unpopular and do not solve problems," added Lin Jian.

⚡️Two Majors

🚨 Iraqi Dinar Revaluation: The Resumption Of Oil 

Today Has Been Historical For Iraq 

Here Is Why

The resumption of Kurdistan crude oil exports through SOMO, as announced on September 16, 2025, cannot proceed to full international market integration without an Iraqi Dinar revaluation and Forex listing this year, as global buyers demand transactions in freely convertible currencies to mitigate exchange rate volatility. This agreement, committing the KRG to supply at least 230,000 barrels per day to SOMO for export, generates revenues primarily in USD, which must be repatriated and converted at a stable, internationally recognized rate to fund federal budget obligations, thereby necessitating a revalued Dinar on Forex to avoid black-market distortions and ensure seamless capital inflows. Without this Forex accessibility, SOMO's marketing of Kurdish oil comparable in quality to Russian grades and targeted at European buyers would face pricing inefficiencies, as hedging contracts require a liquid Dinar pair to lock in profits against IQD fluctuations, directly tying the deal's totality to a year-end revaluation for credible global supply chain participation.

DeFi has unlocked incredible freedom  anyone, anywhere, can trade without asking permission. But freedom came with friction: high gas, failed transactions, and invisible MEV bots constantly skimming value from traders.

Most people got used to it. Some even call it “the cost of being on chain.”

VeloraDEX looks at it differently. What if trading didn’t have to feel like a fight? What if instead of battling against the system, the system was designed to compete for you?

That’s the essence of intent-based trading. Instead of telling the blockchain exactly how to execute a trade, you just state your intent  “I want to swap X for Y at the best price.” From there, a network of solvers competes to give you the best outcome.

The shift is powerful:

Gasless execution → you only pay when a trade succeeds, no wasted ETH.

MEV protection → bots don’t get to front-run your moves.

Sharper prices → solvers battle each other to fill your order efficiently.

Real traction → $12B+ quarterly volume and 18k+ active traders show it’s more than theory.

Here’s where the curiosity kicks in: if intent-based systems already make swaps safer and cheaper, what happens when this expands? Imagine borrowing, lending, or cross-chain swaps where you never worry about bridges, failed tx, or hidden costs  just your intent, and the system delivers.

That’s what VeloraDEX is quietly building toward. It’s not just about making swaps better. It’s about reshaping DeFi around the user instead of the machine.

So the real question isn’t whether intent-based DeFi works  it’s how soon before it becomes the new standard.

🤪Kurdistan salaries suspended pending oil... Cabinet meeting ends without decision
Oil exports from the Kurdistan Region have been a contentious issue since 2014, when the KRG began selling crude independently of Baghdad. I've traded crude oil for 20 years and have watch this drama unfold for years, so this is not surprising.

Disputes over revenue sharing and federal oversight over KRG oil have repeatedly led to disruptions in exports. 

An informed source revealed, on Tuesday (September 16, 2025), that the Council of Ministers concluded its meeting without making a decision regarding the disbursement of salaries to employees of the Kurdistan Region.

The source explained to Baghdad Today that the government is linking salary funding to the implementation of the oil export agreement, stressing that this condition remains an obstacle to the release of funds allocated to the region's employees.

The Kurdistan Region's employee payroll has been complicated for years by disputes between Baghdad and Erbil over oil exports and financial revenues.

The federal government asserts that salary disbursements are linked to the implementation of oil agreements and ensuring revenues reach the public treasury. Meanwhile, the regional government demands that salaries be disbursed without any preconditions, as this is a legal entitlement for its employees.

Seylan Bank Collaborates with Browns EV to Drive Green Mobility with Exclusive Leasing Facilities

Seylan Bank PLC has entered a strategic partnership with Browns EV, the dedicated electric vehicle arm of Browns - a pioneering name in vehicle imports in Sri Lanka. The collaboration introduces an exclusive leasing facility for customers looking to purchase EVs from Browns EV, providing unmatched convenience, competitive financial solutions, and accelerated approvals.

The agreement aligns with Seylan Bank’s commitment to promoting sustainable transportation and supporting Sri Lanka’s transition to green mobility. Under the new facility, customers can obtain leases with repayment periods of up to 7 years. Eligible applicants benefit from fast-track approvals within 24 hours, ensuring swift and hassle-free access to electric vehicle ownership.

Seylan Bank’s leasing solutions are designed with customer convenience at the forefront. Interest rates start at 10% (A.I.R), and customers benefit from the expertise of Dedicated Leasing Specialists who provide doorstep assistance and free consultancy services throughout the leasing process. With its island-wide branch network, Seylan Bank offers end-to-end guidance, from documentation to post-approval services.

Commenting on the partnership, Eugene Seneviratne, DGM Retail Banking, Seylan Bank, said, “By collaborating with Browns EV, we are not only making sustainable mobility more accessible but also reaffirming our commitment to environmental responsibility. Our fast-track approvals and customer-focused leasing options will help more Sri Lankans embrace the future of transport.”

Niveyn Nanayakkara, Director - Browns Ev Limited, stated, “We are pleased to partner with Seylan Bank to provide our customers with flexible, competitive, and fast leasing solutions. This collaboration will make EV ownership more accessible and accelerate the shift towards a cleaner, greener Sri Lanka.”

This partnership between Seylan Bank and Browns EV highlights the importance of innovation and sustainability in shaping the future of mobility. Customers can now explore Browns EV’s range of electric vehicles and secure tailored leasing plans to suit their needs.

For more details, contact the Seylan Bank hotline at 011-200 88 88.

@gaib_ai is turning that oil into a liquid market you can actually trade.

What is GAIB?
A financial layer for AI compute.

Although it's RWA but different from @plumenetwork because it takes GPUs, the engines powering AI and turns them into on-chain assets.

Instead of sitting in data centers, these machines become productive capital anyone can access.

How it works:

▪️GAIB has created AID, a synthetic dollar that is backed by the yield from AI computing resources.

▪️You can stake AID into sAID and earn some yield without losing liquidity.

▪️Data centers and providers can use GPUs to get some funds through GAIB.

Everything ties back to DeFi: lending, borrowing, and yield strategies.

Why does it matter?

Compute is scarce, expensive, and controlled by a handful of giants but GAIB opens that market that:

▪️Investors get access to compute yields

▪️Providers get financing to expand infrastructure

▪️DeFi gains a new class of real-world assets tied to AI growth

What makes Gaib unique? 

▪️GPUs tokenized as financial assets

▪️A synthetic dollar (AID) tied to real yield

▪️DeFi strategies built directly on compute

▪️Expansion into robotics and embodied AI, making even machines financially liquid

This is not simply another AI token following the trend.

It is a new financial engine for what is arguably the most valuable resource of this era: computing power.

Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said on September 18 that Mexico, the U.S., and Canada will continue to uphold the current U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

She emphasized that most exports remain tariff-free despite U.S. duties, and all three nations agree the pact still supports regional trade. Mexico and Canada will strengthen its implementation, with Sheinbaum set to meet PM Justin Trudeau to advance cooperation.

The USMCA replaced NAFTA in 2020 and runs for 16 years, with six-year reviews. The first review starts in July 2026.

Mexico began a 60-day public consultation on September 17 to gather feedback ahead of the review.

🔥The recent agreement between the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) and Baghdad on the resumption of oil exports
Under the deal, the Kurdistan Region will supply its daily oil production to Iraq. In return, Baghdad is obliged to allocate one trillion Iraqi dinars to the Kurdistan Region.
Clickbaiters told you over an over it's delay was for a new rate: total BS

The delay was because Baghdadi and Kurdistan have have different models for contracts with international oil companies (IOCs)
1. Federal Gov. is a Service Contracts model for IOCs
Government hires (pays the money upfront) to IOCs as contractors to explore, develop, and produce oil. IOCs are paid a fixed fee plus a share of production for their services.

2. KRG is a Production Sharing Contracts  Model
IOCs act as partners, funding all exploration and development risks. They receive a share of the produced oil (after cost recovery) as profit, with the government taking the remainder.

The Fed Gov. service contracts prioritize government control   while KRG PSCs Production Sharing Contracts  Model with no state outlay upfront and profit sharing. 
Baghdad pivot toward PSC-like elements (as in this deal) reflects necessity...its liquidity crunch makes the KRG's model more viable, 

💫To read full Article

The recent agreement between the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) and Baghdad on the resumption of oil exports has been hailed as a landmark achievement for the Kurdistan Region, with potential ripple effects across Iraq’s energy policy, according to energy and oil contracts expert Dilshad Muwani,

Muwani emphasized that the deal represents not only an economic and political win for Erbil but also a structural shift in how Iraq manages its oil sector.

Key Provisions of the Agreement

Under the deal, the Kurdistan Region will supply its daily oil production to Iraq. In return, Baghdad is obliged to allocate one trillion Iraqi dinars to the Kurdistan Region.

Muwani stressed that this arrangement strengthens the KRG’s position:

“The Kurdistan Region is the major winner in this agreement. Iraq is effectively forced to provide budgetary support to the Region in exchange for access to its oil production.”

Baghdad’s Shift Toward Production Sharing

The agreement underscores Iraq’s worsening cash crisis, which has constrained its ability to sustain traditional oil service contracts. Under the service contract model, the Iraqi government pays upfront for exploration and production costs and later compensates companies with a portion of the extracted oil.

However, Muwani noted that Iraq no longer has the liquidity to maintain this system:

“Iraq does not have enough cash to invest in oil fields and drill new wells. It cannot pursue service contracts in which the government pays the cost of extraction and then rewards companies with oil.”

By contrast, the Kurdistan Region has long relied on Production Sharing Contracts (PSCs), in which foreign companies cover exploration and drilling costs in exchange for a negotiated share of production. This model suited the KRG in its early years, when it lacked robust oil infrastructure and sufficient investment capital.

Now, faced with a fiscal crunch, Baghdad appears to be shifting closer to the Kurdistan model.

“Due to its liquidity crisis, Iraq is forced to resort to production-sharing mechanisms. This reduces the financial burden on the federal government and encourages foreign companies to invest without Baghdad having to allocate large amounts of cash,” Muwani explained.

Implications for Iraq’s Energy Policy

Analysts argue that the agreement could mark a turning point for Iraq’s broader oil strategy. The deal not only ensures a steady flow of revenue for the Kurdistan Region but also signals Baghdad’s willingness to embrace new contractual models.

Muwani underlined the significance of this shift: “The agreement between the Kurdistan Region and Baghdad is not only an economic and political achievement for Erbil, but it will also reshape Iraq’s oil policy. Iraq’s move toward co-production contracts represents an important transformation that requires deeper research to assess its long-term impact.”

The alignment of federal oil policy with the KRG’s PSC framework could also pave the way for greater stability in investor relations, potentially making Iraq more attractive to international energy companies seeking predictable, profit-sharing arrangements.

The resumption of oil exports from the Kurdistan Region represents more than a budgetary lifeline. It underscores Baghdad’s growing reliance on the production-sharing model pioneered by the KRG, driven by its own financial crisis. If managed wisely, this shift could stabilize Iraq’s energy sector, attract foreign investment, and redefine federal-regional relations in the oil industry.

Still, the long-term implications—both political and economic—remain uncertain. As Muwani concludes, the agreement “draws a new map for oil relations in Iraq” and requires careful policy planning to maximize benefits for both Baghdad and Erbil while ensuring regional energy stability.

⭕️ Iran exports advanced gas turbine to Russia for first time

Iran has delivered an advanced gas turbine to Russia for the first time, Energy Minister Abbas Aliabadi announced on Tuesday, calling it a significant step for the country’s power industry in the face of Western sanctions.

At a national gathering for exporters of engineering services and power equipment, Aliabadi said the shipment featured a domestically developed turbine considered among the most sophisticated achievements of Iran’s electricity sector. He noted that Iran has also supplied generators and other electrical systems to Russia, in addition to conducting aircraft engine overhauls.

The minister stressed that exports are most meaningful when based on local innovation and added value. “For years, we have relied on mineral sales and crude exports, but exports are only a source of pride when they create value and deliver innovation,” he said.

(Tehran Times)

Iraq nears deal to restart Kurdish oil exports through Turkey: report https://t.co/tvAy2PRo3Q

Barzani Signals Breakthrough on Oil Exports: A Turning Point for Iraq and Kurdistan

At the inauguration of the Sheikhan–Lalish road project in Duhok, Kurdistan Region Prime Minister Masrour Barzani delivered a statement that could redefine Iraq’s energy map. He confirmed that the federal government in Baghdad and International Oil Companies (IOCs) operating in the Region have reached a broad understanding—one that may soon unlock the long-stalled resumption of Kurdish oil exports.

Geopolitical Context
For 18 months, Kurdish crude has been absent from international markets after exports through Turkey’s Ceyhan pipeline were suspended in March 2023. The freeze has drained more than \$30 billion from Iraq and the Kurdistan Region, tightening fiscal space, reducing investment flows, and weakening confidence in the country’s oil sector. The new understanding marks a step toward reconciling Iraq’s competing power centers: Baghdad’s federal control and Erbil’s autonomous energy policy. If implemented, it would not only restore vital revenues but also stabilize relations with Ankara, which has been eager to see the pipeline reopened under a clear legal framework.

Banking and Fiscal Dimensions
Beyond oil, Barzani underscored Erbil’s cooperation with Baghdad on budget and salary disputes, stressing that “no obstacles have ever been created” from Kurdistan’s side. A July deal already set terms: Erbil agreed to transfer 230,000 barrels per day to SOMO and remit 120 billion Iraqi dinars in non-oil revenues, in return for federal salary disbursements. Yet delays persist—civil servants only received June salaries in September, while July and August remain unpaid. Such gaps undermine public trust and highlight the urgent need for more predictable federal transfers and financial discipline.

Currency and Economic Outlook
Should oil exports resume, Iraq’s macroeconomic landscape could shift significantly. Restoring over 400,000 barrels per day from the Kurdistan Region would inject billions in foreign exchange into Iraq’s reserves, strengthen the Central Bank of Iraq’s ability to defend the dinar, and relieve pressure on the parallel market. Internationally, investors would interpret the breakthrough as a sign of political maturity and institutional coherence, potentially accelerating Iraq’s bid for greater global financial integration, including WTO accession and deeper ties with IFIs.

Outlook
Barzani’s remarks signal more than a technical oil deal—they represent a potential reset of Baghdad–Erbil relations. If Baghdad delivers on salary payments and IOCs receive payment guarantees, the long-awaited flow of Kurdish oil could resume within weeks. This would send a powerful message: Iraq is ready to move past old disputes and harness its full energy potential for national stability and regional influence. For the Kurdistan Region, it would mean fiscal breathing room and renewed faith in partnership with Baghdad. For Iraq as a whole, it would mean reclaiming lost revenues, strengthening its currency base, and demonstrating to global markets that cooperation, not fragmentation, defines its future.

Krasnov-Trump cannot copy the RU-economy 

1. Russia’s stance

Russia has little incentive to push renewables. Its economy is tied to oil, gas, coal, uranium exports.

So Moscow tends to block, ridicule, or underfund solar, wind, hydrogen—anything that threatens fossil rents.

Instead, Russia talks up “nuclear pride” and keeps energy policy centralized.

2. Trump’s stance

He isn’t against energy tech in principle, but he treats solar/wind/hydrogen as “losers” compared to oil, gas, coal.

Example: Trump often mocks wind (“kills birds, noisy, too expensive”), downplays solar, and puts tariffs on imported solar panels.

He favors fossil dominance + protectionist tariffs, which echoes the Russian way of guarding incumbents, not innovating.

3. The big difference

The U.S. has a strong private sector in renewables—Silicon Valley, Tesla, hydrogen startups, etc.—and they thrive globally even when the White House resists.

Russia doesn’t have that open innovation engine.

So Trump’s policies tilt the field against renewables, but the market forces and states (California, Texas wind, etc.) still keep them alive.

So yes: Trump does lean Russia’s way—protecting fossil rents, ridiculing green tech, and throwing tariffs around.
But unlike Russia, the U.S. economy is too diverse: innovation keeps breaking through no matter how much political leadership resists.

The UAE and Colombian Mercenaries in Sudan’s War: Oil Money Fueling a Trade in Blood

Middle East Eye published a report titled “From Sudan to Ukraine: Why Colombian mercenaries keep fighting foreign wars” by journalist Iñigo Alexander, exposing the central role of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) in recruiting and financing Colombian mercenaries to fight alongside the Rapid Support Militia (Janjaweed) against the Sudanese Armed Forces.

According to the report, Sudanese military authorities submitted a formal letter to the UN Security Council stating that they had collected “extensive evidence” of “a systematic campaign by the UAE to undermine peace, security, and the sovereignty of Sudan, through the recruitment, financing, and deployment of mercenaries fighting alongside the Rapid Support Militia (Janjaweed).” While Khartoum presented these findings, Abu Dhabi flatly denied the allegations.

The recruitment process, as the investigation reveals, was orchestrated through a Colombian private security firm contracted by an Emirati company called Global Security Services Group. These mercenaries were deployed to fight within a battalion known as the “Desert Wolves,” commanded by a retired Colombian general based in Dubai — evidence that the operational hub of this network is managed from within the UAE itself.

The routes used to move the mercenaries to Sudan were not improvised but carefully structured. Initially, mercenaries traveled from Abu Dhabi to Benghazi in Libya, where their passports were confiscated to prevent them from returning home. As this pathway became widely known, the UAE facilitated alternative routes through Madrid, Ethiopia, and the Somali port city of Bosaso, then onward to N’Djamena in Chad, before finally arriving in Nyala, a city under Janjaweed control in Darfur.

Testimonies from the mercenaries themselves highlight the grim reality of this system. One Colombian soldier said in an audio recording: “Things are ugly here, we’re being held captive.” Another described it bluntly: “This is human trafficking. They hire us for one thing, and then take us somewhere else to do something different.” These accounts expose the exploitative nature of a network overseen and financed by Abu Dhabi.

Professor Sean McFate of the U.S. National Defense University noted that Colombians are considered “excellent fighters with a lot of combat experience and strong discipline,” and at the same time “cost a quarter of what an American mercenary would cost.” He added: “The UAE is a huge consumer of mercenary services. They have the money, they have the geopolitical ambitions to dominate the Middle East and parts of North Africa. There is demand from the Janjaweed, money from the UAE, and supply from Colombia.”

The report concludes that the UAE is not merely a secondary supporter but an active player fueling Sudan’s war through its vast oil wealth, turning former Colombian soldiers into a cheap commodity in the marketplace of conflict. This role not only escalates Sudan’s suffering but also undermines prospects for peace and shields perpetrators from accountability, as the use of mercenaries allows state actors like Abu Dhabi to wage proxy wars behind a cloak of plausible deniability.

The pipeline, once carrying 400,000 barrels per day, is expected to play a key role in easing disputes over revenue management and distribution.

🔥Boom! KRG, Baghdad, Oil Firms Sign Deal to Resume Kurdistan Oil Exports💥

ERBIL – The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), Iraq’s Ministry of Oil, and oil-producing companies have signed a trilateral agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region, BasNews has learned.

The agreement, signed Monday afternoon in Erbil, clears the way for the re-export of Kurdish crude through Turkey’s Ceyhan port after more than two years of suspension. 

The deal is expected to be formally announced by Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani at Tuesday’s Iraqi Council of Ministers meeting, where further details will be released.

Earlier in the day, a technical delegation from Iraq’s state-run North Oil Company visited Erbil to finalize export procedures. The delegation held a four-hour meeting with the KRG’s Ministry of Natural Resources, paving the way for the deal’s conclusion.

Under the agreement, the Kurdistan Region will hand over 230,000 barrels of crude per day to the State Organization for Marketing of Oil (SOMO), while retaining 50,000 barrels for domestic consumption. Exports will flow to Ceyhan via the North Oil Company.

KRG spokesperson Peshawa Hawramani had told BasNews on Monday that such a deal was imminent, stressing that it would remove obstacles to the transfer of federal salaries to Kurdistan Region employees.

Oil exports from the Kurdistan Region through Ceyhan were halted in March 2023 following a ruling by the International Chamber of Commerce’s Court of Arbitration in Paris.

The court found that Turkey had violated a 1973 pipeline agreement by allowing Erbil to independently export crude without Baghdad’s consent between 2014 and 2018, ordering Ankara to pay $1.5 billion in damages to Iraq.

Although Turkey has appealed the ruling, it has signaled readiness to reopen the pipeline once Baghdad and Erbil reach an internal settlement. The suspension has cost the KRG billions of dollars in revenue and deepened its reliance on federal budget transfers to cover public sector salaries.

The resumption of exports is seen as a breakthrough for both Erbil and Baghdad, potentially easing long-standing disputes over oil and revenue sharing while reassuring international oil companies invested in the Kurdistan Region.

🚨BREAKING UPDATE Kurdistan Oil Exports to Resume via Ceyhan Port on September 23
🎉Thank God this Drama is over 🎉
🚩BTW When it's 8:00AM in Iraq it's 1:00AM east coast time 10:00PM west coast time in the USA
💫Kurdistan Region will resume on Tuesday, September 23, 2025, through the Ceyhan port in Turkey, under the supervision of Iraq’s State Organization for Marketing of Oil (SOMO).

The process of exporting oil from the Kurdistan Region is nearing its conclusion, with expectations that the export operations will officially resume within the next two days.

Delegations from Kurdistan and Oil Companies to Visit Baghdad Tomorrow

A delegation from the Kurdistan Regional Government’s Ministry of Natural Resources, along with representatives from oil companies, will visit Baghdad tomorrow. The purpose of this visit is to finalize the agreement regarding the resumption of oil exports from the Kurdistan Region with the Iraqi government and Iraq’s Ministry of Oil.

Tripartite Meeting to Resolve Outstanding Issues

A tripartite meeting has been scheduled between the Kurdistan Regional Government’s Ministry of Natural Resources, oil companies, and Iraq’s Ministry of Oil. This meeting will take place at the headquarters of Iraq’s Ministry of Oil in Baghdad. The Sources indicate that during this meeting, the parties will address and resolve the remaining obstacles and concerns related to restarting oil exports from the Kurdistan Region. If any further issues arise, they will be discussed and unified during this session. This meeting is intended to reach a settlement and will yield concrete results.

Exports to Resume via SOMO and Ceyhan Port

According to the same sources, the agreement between Iraq’s Ministry of Oil, the Kurdistan Region, and the oil companies will be finalized during tomorrow’s meeting. The report emphasizes that following the ratification of the agreement, oil exports from the Kurdistan Region will resume on Tuesday, September 23, 2025, through the Ceyhan port in Turkey, under the supervision of Iraq’s State Organization for Marketing of Oil (SOMO).

Production and Distribution Details

Currently, the Kurdistan Region produces approximately 233,000 barrels of oil per day from its fields. Under the terms of the agreement, 50,000 barrels per day will be allocated for domestic consumption within the Kurdistan Region, while the remaining volume will be handed over to SOMO for export. In accordance with Iraq’s budget law, the Ministry of Oil is obligated to cover the costs of production and transportation, paying $16 per barrel to the oil-producing companies operating in Kurdistan.

KRG Announces Landmark Agreement to Resume Oil Exports Starting 6:00 AM, Saturday, September 27, 2025

The Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG) expressed its satisfaction with reaching a trilateral agreement to resume oil exports from the Kurdistan Region. The government emphasized that this step could strengthen financial stability and help resolve the salary crisis affecting public employees in the region.

Summary of the Agreement

The agreement consists of six main and preliminary articles and was formally signed by Iraq’s Ministry of Oil, the KRG’s Ministry of Natural Resources, and participating oil companies. It clearly outlines the rights, obligations, and commitments of all three parties involved.

Resumption of Oil Exports

It has been decided that at exactly 6:00 AM on Saturday, September 27, 2025, oil from the Kurdistan Region will once again flow through the Kurdistan–Ceyhan pipeline to international markets.

Financial and Marketing Mechanism

Under the new agreement, Iraq’s State Oil Marketing Organization (SOMO) will take responsibility for marketing Kurdistan’s oil. The revenue from oil sales will be transferred to the federal treasury in Baghdad. Simultaneously, non-oil revenues from the Kurdistan Region will also be deposited into the federal treasury. This arrangement ensures that the Kurdistan Region contributes to Iraq’s overall revenue growth.

KRG: Ending the Salary Crisis

According to the KRG’s official statement, the primary goal of this agreement is to resolve the salary crisis and ensure financial fairness for the Kurdistan Region. The government expressed hope that the deal would lead to consistent salary payments and end the uncertainty faced by public employees. It stressed the importance of separating salary issues from political disputes. Revenues will be allocated within the framework of Iraq’s national budget to cover the Region’s salary and financial entitlements.

Revealing its role, Washington: The Baghdad-Kurdistan agreement will enhance regional energy security

US Secretary of State Mike Rubio revealed on Thursday Washington's role in the Baghdad-Kurdistan Region agreement to resume oil exports, stressing that it will enhance "regional security."

"We welcome the announcement that the Government of Iraq has reached an agreement with the Kurdistan Regional Government and international companies to reopen the Iraq-Turkey pipeline, an agreement facilitated by the United States that will deliver tangible benefits to Americans and Iraqis alike," Rubio said in a press statement.

He added, "We commend the decisive efforts of Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani and senior Iraqi government officials, as well as Kurdistan Regional Government Prime Minister Masrour Barzani and senior KRG officials, to achieve this progress."

He continued, "This agreement will strengthen the mutually beneficial economic partnership between the United States and Iraq, encourage a more stable investment environment across Iraq for American companies, enhance regional energy security, and strengthen Iraqi sovereignty."

Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani announced Thursday evening that he had reached an oil agreement with the Kurdistan Region, describing it as "historic." The federal Ministry of Oil indicated that the agreement is the result of ongoing efforts over the past months to establish clear mechanisms to ensure smooth export flows and transparency in revenues .

It's worth noting that the Kurdistan Regional Government's Ministry of Natural Resources, the Iraqi Ministry of Oil, and oil companies signed a tripartite agreement last Monday, paving the way for the resumption of the export of Kurdistan Region oil via the Ceyhan pipeline.

Kurdistan Region oil exports were halted on March 25, 2023, following an international arbitration ruling requiring Turkey not to allow the region's oil exports without the approval of the federal government in Baghdad .

Since then, shipments of an estimated 450,000 barrels per day have been disrupted, including 400,000 from the Kurdistan Region and 50,000 from the northern Kirkuk fields. This disruption has resulted in daily financial losses exceeding $30 million, according to unofficial estimates.

Help me congratulate Dr. Phoutvichay LINSOMPHOU on the successful completion of his PhD under my supervision. His dissertation examines how infrastructure connectivity, trade integration, and renewable energy development shape economic growth in ASEAN countries, filling a major gap in the trade–growth literature. Unlike studies that focus narrowly on trade volume or rely on growth models with assumptions ill-suited for low-income economies, his research highlights the importance of aligning factor-intensive trade with connectivity modes. Using a dual framework—a modified Jones (1996) semi-endogenous model and an augmented Solow model—it shows that growth in ASEAN depends not on openness alone but on the interaction of trade, infrastructure, and renewable energy. The findings are especially striking for countries like Lao PDR, where renewable energy intensity and human capital amplify the growth effects of capital-intensive trade when supported by efficient transport systems. As a supervisor, it is deeply rewarding to witness such scholarly achievement, which also reminds me with gratitude of the guidance once given by my own PhD mentor.

#Robotics Trade Idea:  MP Materials $MP is up 300% over the last year with plenty more room to run.  $MP supplies $TSLA, $GM, and the Pentagon

The muscle of the robots comes from raw materials giving robots strength.

This is often overlooked and consists of metals, magnets, and batteries providing power and motion to robots. 

Think about how smooth a robot has to be to do precision surgery on a human being. That is because of magnets. 

These come from rare earth elements that must be mined and are currently scarce because of how long mines can take to create. You need lightweight neodymium-iron-boron (NdFeB) magnets for robots.

With demand surging for robots, you need about 2 - 4 pounds of rare-earth magnets per humanoid and the scale is expected to be able to produce billions of robots by 2050.

You need supply chain security and China is dominating this space right now. US firms are building domestic capabilities, but a huge risk to the US and advancement is the fact that China is dominating this right now.

I think you’re going to see public companies come out of nowhere and get mass government funding because the US is scared to fall behind.

In comes MP Materials - a US rare earth mine and magnet plant. It supplies Tesla, GM, and the Pentagon covering 15% of global output. They’re the leader in the US for sure and a great play to own long term.

Demand has soared for rare earth materials, owning companies like $MP is important for your portfolio because the materials will get cheaper and cheaper to produce, but demand is skyrocketing allowing unlimited inflation in the cost to buy those materials.

One big challenge to overcome, beyond cost, is that batteries may only last 2-4 hours per charge. There needs to be more innovation here to overcome this limitation.

The $TSLA breakout is a good lesson in what to look for if you want to swing big.

Let’s start with the technicals of this trade.

We see that the stock suffered a major decline, bottomed in April around $220, pushed to $350, then spent over four months consolidating between $300 and $350. This is a textbook pattern, a big decline, big advance off a low, followed by a long consolidation.

This allowed all key moving averages to tighten on the daily and weekly timeframe.

The most important technical aspect of this trade is the volatility contraction. May to September volatility slowly decreased and price action tightened. If you start in May, the pullbacks got less severe as the base progressed. 

From the peak in May to the breakout in September, the declines were: -26%, -20%, -13%, -10%, -9%.

This is textbook, less sellers continued to show up as the base progressed. From contraction comes expansion.

The narrative and fundamental aspect of the trade is what juiced it further.

Tesla has bet its entire future on AI. While other big tech names only had AI as part of their business, Tesla was betting the company on it. The AI trade is progressing, people are looking for who can actually apply AI to physical products. Robotics and autonomous driving are the pinnacle of AI and Tesla was already seen as the face of both. The Robotaxi app wide release also came just days before the breakout.

The macro backdrop had turned supportive. Rate cut talk picked up after Jackson Hole and lower borrowing costs means easier car financing for consumers and more enterprise investment into Tesla energy.

Earnings have been poor which means earnings comps going forward are extremely low after many weak quarters. That sets the stage for even EPS and revenue growth to flip the narrative. The market is forward looking.

There is also a major shift in sentiment around Elon. He’s stepped back from politics and referred to it as a side quest in his past. That showed his commitment to Tesla which had been in question for over a year.

The biggest piece was his new compensation package which tied his $ directly to autonomy, robotics, and FSD adoption. The milestones are astronomical which aligned his incentives with shareholders.

If you missed this trade don’t sweat it, just know these opportunities present themselves over and over again so try and be ready next time. The best trades have much more than a nice chart, all of the stars aligned.

A proud moment for Indraprastha Gas Limited!

The new Corporate Office of IGL at World Trade Centre, Tower G, 2nd Floor, Nauroji Nagar, New Delhi was inaugurated today by Mr. Hardeep Singh Puri, Hon’ble Union Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas, in the august presence of Shri Pankaj Jain, Secretary, Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas; Mr. Sandeep Kumar Gupta, CMD, GAIL (India) Ltd.; Mr. Raj Kumar Dubey, Chairman IGL, Mr. Kamal Kishore Chatiwal, Managing Director, IGL and Mr. Mohit Bhatia, Director (Commercial), IGL, along with other senior officials. 
While inaugurating the office, Mr Puri emphasized IGL’s contribution in extending piped natural gas (PNG) connections to 250 villages in Delhi, benefiting over 1 lakh rural households. He said this initiative is helping provide urban amenities such as clean cooking fuel in rural areas, bridging the rural-urban divide. Each CNG station, PNG connection, and pipeline expansion contributes to reducing emissions, improving air quality, and strengthening India’s clean energy future.

Congratulating IGL on its new office, Mr. Puri said, “IGL’s journey has been one of innovation, growth, and social impact. This new office reaffirms its commitment to expanding reach, strengthening operations, and advancing India’s clean energy transition.” @HardeepSPuri @PetroleumMin  #IGL

Key regions poised for this clean coal revival:

Pennsylvania: In PJM (~20% coal, 7% renewables), clean coal boosts exports and stability. (See the Note at the bottom of this post for PJM's unique coal generation benefits)

Wyoming:
Coal powers 80% of the grid, with wind/solar at 15%. Clean coal replaces retiring plants, ensuring steady baseload in the Western Interconnection.

West Virginia: In PJM (~20% coal, 7% renewables), clean coal sustains reliability and jobs.

Illinois: MISO grid, 25% wind, 5% solar. Clean coal anchors baseload for consistent power.

Montana: Western Interconnection, 15% renewables. Clean coal enhances exports and reliability.

By replacing aging plants, down from 310 GW in 2010 to 180 GW in 2023, clean coal complements renewables for a strong grid, cost effective grid, a prerequisite to any industrial revival in our heartland.

PJM’s Capacity Market:
- Clean coal boosts supply, curbing rate hikes (📉 vs. 22% spike for 2026).
- Replaces retiring coal plants (20% by 2028).
- Reliable baseload power, unlike wind/solar (1-3% of capacity).
- Diversifies PJM’s mix (coal at 22%), ensuring stability.

‘Modi's Stance Reflects National Interest’
Lavrov On US Pressure On India Over Russian Oil

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov emphasized that trade conditions between India and Russia will be decided solely by the two countries, dismissing increasing US pressure on India regarding its energy dealings with Russia. 

Speaking to Sputnik India, Lavrov said this stance reflects India’s national interest, pride, and honor. He criticized the US assumption that India would negotiate oil purchases on American terms as flawed. 

Lavrov reiterated that all trade discussions are strictly bilateral matters between Russia and India. His comments come amid ongoing US efforts to dissuade New Delhi from buying Russian crude oil, highlighting the close and independent nature of India-Russia relations in the energy sector.

China’s own shale gas revolution

China has become the world’s largest gas importer following the government’s decision to convert urban heating systems from coal to reduce air pollution and carbon dioxide emissions. 

Imports increased to a record 180 billion cubic metres (roughly 130 million tonnes) in 2024 up from zero less than two decades ago owing to the rapid growth in consumption.  

China relied on imports to satisfy more than 40% of its consumption last year having been self-sufficient as recently as 2005. 

Dependence on imports would be a major vulnerability in the event of a future conflict with the United States and its allies. 

But increasing imports have obscured China’s phenomenal success boosting domestic production through a mix of planning targets and price incentives. ...

1. Venezuela’s Oil Wealth

Venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves in the world, even more than Saudi Arabia.

Oil makes up about 95% of Venezuela’s exports and is the backbone of its economy.

2. U.S. Sanctions & Economic Collapse

In the 2010s, the U.S. imposed heavy sanctions on Venezuela’s oil industry (especially on state oil company PDVSA).

These sanctions were meant to pressure Nicolás Maduro’s government.

The result: Venezuela was cut off from the U.S. financial system, couldn’t sell oil freely, and its currency collapsed.

This triggered hyperinflation, with basic goods costing millions of bolívars.

3. China Steps In

While the U.S. tried to choke Venezuela economically, China and Russia stepped in as lifelines.

China has loan-for-oil deals with Venezuela, meaning Venezuela sends crude in exchange for Chinese financing.

In recent years, China buys much of Venezuela’s sanctioned oil at a discount, rerouting it through middlemen or blending it to hide its origin.

4. Why the U.S. Wants It

The U.S. still wants access to Venezuelan oil because:

It’s close geographically (cheap transport compared to Middle East).

It could help stabilize oil prices and reduce dependence on OPEC and hostile states.

American refineries are built to process Venezuela’s heavy crude.

5. The Big Picture

Venezuela’s crisis wasn’t just from “bad socialism” or “mismanagement” — U.S. sanctions crushed its ability to sell oil legally.

China filled the gap, securing cheap energy while building political influence in Latin America.

Now the U.S. is reconsidering its stance, since blocking Venezuela only pushed it deeper into China’s orbit.
